nytimes_articles.headline: Second Generations Try to Heal Wounds From World War II
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FOR many years Alan Berkowitz did not know about his father's life in the forest. Mr. Berkowitz, 33, a West Hartford resident, said that when he was growing up, he tried to find out how his father, who died when Mr. Berkowitz was 10, had survived the Holocaust. But whenever he questioned his grandmother, the soft-spoken woman would say in a firm voice, "The war is over." 

Mr. Berkowitz began to piece together his father's past on a trip to Israel during college when he met a cousin who explained how Mr. Berkowitz's father, at the age of 12, had escaped with his parents into the woods in December of 1942, two days before the Nazis murdered the Jewish people in their town or transported them to concentration camps. The family lived in the forest with partisans until the area was liberated about two year later.

nytimes_articles.headline: Phoenix Tapping Local Acting Pool
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THIS summer will be a season of firsts for the Phoenix Theater, based at the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase. 

On Thursday the Phoenix will hold a gala benefit at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, featuring performances by Alan Arkin and Ellen Burstyn. Mr. Arkin, who lives in Chappaqua, and Ms. Burstyn, a Nyack resident, "are great friends" but have never worked together on stage, said Bram Lewis, the theater's artistic director. They will read from two one-act plays by Murray Schisgal, "The Typists" and "The Tiger."

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Not Over Till It's Over: Grandparents as 'Parents'
nytimes_articles.abstract: "MY friends are playing golf, and I'm playing tiddlywinks," Marion Werle said. With silver strands among her golden hair, Mrs. Werle, 56, doesn't appear to be the typical tiddlywinks champ. One would expect her leisure time to be spent at a bridge table or on a putting green. Instead she races behind a wobbly two-wheeler or plays children's games in her small apartment in Coram.   Mrs. Werle is one of the growing number of Long Island grandparents who have custody of their grandchildren. "I've had Jennifer since she was 2," she said. "I thought this would be temporary. My daughter is a substance abuser."

nytimes_articles.headline: William McCarthy 3d, Eileen Libutti
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eileen Hope Libutti, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Libutti of Lido Beach, L.I., was married last evening to William Joseph McCarthy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William McCarthy of Chicago. The Rev. Roland Ghirlando, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Sands, a catering establishment in Atlantic Beach, L.I. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich took part in the ceremony.   Mrs. McCarthy, 26, is an associate at Rivkin, Radler & Kremer, a law firm in Uniondale, L.I. She and her husband graduated from Boston University. The bride received a law degree from New York Law School. Her father is a senior vice president in East Rutherford, N.J., for the Sequa Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of aerospace, machinery and metal coatings. Her mother, Phyllis Libutti, teaches third grade at the Lindell Elementary School in Long Beach.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Challenge? Not Much of One
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor   It is an unfortunate message the racing industry sends to the public when it rewards an already super-rich "sportsman" with a million-dollar bonus for owning a horse only good enough to finish seventh. That's what happened as a result of the recent Belmont Stakes, the climactic event in a promotion sponsored by an automobile company. Because the rules of the Chrysler Triple Crown Challenge insist that a horse must finish all three races in the series, Prairie Bayou, the Preakness winner who broke down in the Belmont and subsequently had to be destroyed, was eliminated from consideration despite having amassed the most points in the series.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pastor Fugard Warns of Judgment Day
nytimes_articles.abstract: Of all the questions that are asked in the course of "Playland," the latest drama by the South African playwright Athol Fugard, one is bound to leap out at you: "What is it that makes a man feel sorry?"   Philosophically, the provocative line stands out on its own merits. Why does one man repent and not another? But it also goes to the very heart of Mr. Fugard's drama, which can currently be found at Stage II of the Manhattan Theater Club. In that respect, I wish it didn't call so much attention to itself. Mr. Fugard is skirting sermons here, and a playwright as accomplished as he shouldn't have to state his concerns this overtly.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Browsers Welcome; House-Hunting, Via Video
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's a bit like an upscale Co-ops 'R' Us.   The first thing you notice is the window. Angels, lots of angels, with gold wings, lyres and trumpets, hanging from strings, heralding from on high the delights of "full park views," "terrace in bloom," "charming CPW pre-war." Stripped in red across the glass, the list expands: "East Side"; "West Side"; "Downtown"; "Lofts"; "Town Houses"; "Weekend Retreats." A typical real-estate office? No. "Walk through apartments on video," the signs exhort, "Check out recent sales in your building," "See what your apartment is worth."

nytimes_articles.headline: Andrew Gurley Jr. and Allison Kahler
nytimes_articles.abstract: Allison Leslie Kahler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Kahler of Timonium, Md., was married yesterday to Andrew Fenn Gurley Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gurley of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. George Gray Toole performed the ceremony at the Towson (Md.) Presbyterian Church.   Mrs. Gurley, 29, is a production merchandiser at the Berkley Shirt Company in New York. She graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology and the University of Maryland. Her father is a human-resources counselor at the Baltimore Medical System Inc., a health-care company in Baltimore. Her mother, Zedith Kahler, owns Flowers by Penny Lane in Reisterstown, Md.

nytimes_articles.headline: McGuire Base Ponders Life After Budget Cuts
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AT 3:30 on a recent Monday morning in the operations building here at McGuire Air Force Base, Maj. Al Polaneczky, a commercial pilot for Delta Air Lines, and an Air Force Reserve pilot with the 514th Air Lift Wing, briefed his crew of eight. At 6 o'clock they were scheduled to take off for Thule, Greenland, America's northern most military base, about 900 miles from the North Pole. A sign in another room reflected the reserve unit's roots: "Operation Security and You, Perfect Together," a word play on an old tourism slogan, "New Jersey and You, Perfect Together."

The weekly flight from McGuire to Thule delivers passengers as well as food and medicine to support the 880 military and civilian personnel stationed there as part of the 12th Space Defense Squadron. "It's an ideal flight for Reserve crews because it's up and back in two or three days," said Brig. Gen. Robert J. Winner, commander of the 514th....

nytimes_articles.headline: Golf's Gamesmanship Is as Subtle as a Controlled Slice
nytimes_articles.abstract: We've heard a lot these days about "trash talk." That's the National Basketball Association's phrase for bench-jockeying, an old baseball tradition. By whatever name, it has to do with getting to an opponent's mind, upsetting his concentration, disrupting his psychological equilibrium.   Some sports purists condemn it as unsportsmanlike. They claim a game should be won solely on physical merits, sheer talent, and perhaps a lucky bounce. But games are played in the mind every bit as much as with the body. The proliferation of sports psychologists on today's scene proves that. It follows then that if the mind is in the action, it's as open to intimidation or coercion as the second baseman is to the runner trying to break up the double play with a spikes-high slide. A Needle Nonetheless    In baseball, basketball, football and hockey, the jockeying of an opponent is usually verbal, very direct, often crude; and, as when Jackie Robinson broke into the major leagues, viciously mean and racist. In golf, jockeying is more subtle, in keeping with the sport's courteous ambiance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: An essay on May 30 about rediscovering a Jewish heritage while traveling omitted part of a sentence. It should have read: "I doubt I will ever yearn to belong to a group of people all singing, as it were, from the same hymnal."

nytimes_articles.headline: Ways to Make the Most of the Strawberry Season
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE local strawberry crop is late this year, as it was last year, making the lush, ripe berries more welcome than ever. The season is now in full swing.    Farm stands and markets throughout the region are overflowing with berries by the quart. Pickers take to the fields, and even some supermarkets have caught on and are selling locally grown strawberries from fields that perfume the air.

nytimes_articles.headline: A German Town's Past Is Gemutlich and Gothic
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN Germany was divided, until 1800, into more than 300 states, even small cities mattered: Landshut, today a bustling town 45 minutes' train ride from Munich, was once the chief residence of a branch of the ruling house of Bavaria. Just far enough to have stayed itself, just prosperous enough to look as picturesque as ever, it is a lively reminder of an earlier, more gemutlich phase of history, and the perfect place for a day trip.   Just as important, Landshut came through World War II without major damage. Today, its churches are intact, and so are the town palace and the fortress on its hill. The main street, the Altstadt, with its sinuous line of gabled houses painted a variety of colors -- from a sober gray or beige to pink, ochre, green or blue -- takes the visitor straight back to the Germany of the Brothers Grimm.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Shows With Links to the Past
nytimes_articles.abstract: WESTCHESTER has returned to the past with two shows, one of tintypes at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, the other of Impressionistic paintings at the Hammond Museum in North Salem.   In the beginning was the daguerreotype, a silvered copper plate in which the reflections of faces, figures and landscape were fixed forever. There was also the calotype, an image made with paper negative and positive. Then came the ambrotype, which is a kind of daguerreotype except that it involves a negative coated with collodion, which becomes a positive when laid on a dark ground. A cheap, virtually mass-produced variant of this was the tintype, an image on a thin sheet of iron, which, when painted, has the look of folk art.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wall Street Weak
nytimes_articles.abstract:
BEAR TRAP
Why Wall Street Doesn't Work.
By Paul Gibson.
246 pp. New York:
The Atlantic Monthly Press.
NIGHTMARE ON WALL STREET

the Corruption of the Marketplace.

Simon & Schuster. $23.

nytimes_articles.headline: Majmudars Turn Cup Into Family Affair
nytimes_articles.abstract: The resemblance emerges on the court and off it. Gina and Kunj Majmudar not only bear similar features as brother and sister, they both have powerful forehands and error-free games that have dominated their opponents in the New York City Mayor's Cup All Scholastic tournament at the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.   This is Gina's fourth Mayor's Cup at the varsity level, and her third chance to defend her championship title. She first won the tournament in 1990 as a freshman at New Dorp High School in Staten Island. She says it was her most difficult final ever; she beat her sister, Mona, then a senior.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clearwater Revival Coming to Valhalla
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT can you do for the father who has everything? Take him -- and the rest of the family -- to Clearwater's Great Hudson River Revival next Saturday or Sunday. Since 1978 the event has been lighting up the Father's Day weekend with song, children's entertainment, crafts, environmental exhibitions andother activities showcasing the rich diversity and abundant talent of the American folk scene.   As in past years, the event takes place on the Valhalla campus of Westchester Community College, offering musical performances, storytelling sessions and do-it-yourself folk dancing more or less continuously -- and simultaneously -- on six outdoor sound stages. The roster of artists ranges from Odetta, Tommy Makem, Pete Seeger and Livingston Taylor to dozens of other solo and group performers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Albania Fears 'Ethnic Cleansing' May Spread to Kosovo Next
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the other side of the border checkpoint in the wooded mountains a half hour's drive from this ragged town, a village of neat white houses is all that is visible of Kosovo, a Serbian province largely populated by ethnic Albanians.   All is quiet except for birdsong, and few guards are about, yet, Albania fears that Kosovo is the flashpoint that could plunge the Balkans into all-out war.

nytimes_articles.headline: Restoring a Battlefield to the Time of George Washington
nytimes_articles.abstract: STANDING at the Visitor Center of Monmouth Battlefield State Park, looking over the gently rolling hillsides, you might find it hard to imagine that hundreds of men died here, amid clouds of cannon smoke and gunpowder, in suffocating midsummer heat.   But it was on this site in June 1778 that American troops under Gen. George Washington caught up with a British force commanded by Gen. Henry Clinton, who was leading his men from Philadelphia to Sandy Hook, where boats would carry them to New York City.

nytimes_articles.headline: THEATER
nytimes_articles.abstract: June    "CAMELOT." Playing the dashing Sir Lancelot du Lac, who lures Queen Guenevere away from King Arthur, Robert Goulet found overnight stardom on Broadway in the original production of Lerner and Loewe's musical. That was in 1960. Now he's back in a touring production of the show about the Knights of the Round Table and their ladies fair. Only this time he's appearing as King Arthur. Among other things, that means he'll be singing "I Wonder What the King Is Doing Tonight" instead of "If Ever I Would Leave You." Steve Blanchard and Patricia Kies are featured as Lancelot and Guenevere. Previews begin Thursday; opens June 21. Gershwin Theater, 221 West 51st, Manhattan. Performances: Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M. No Sunday performances. Tickets: $45 to $65. Information: (212) 307-4100.   "A PERFECT GANESH." Two women, portrayed by Frances Sternhagen and Zoe Caldwell, take a trip to India in the newest play by Terrence McNally. Fisher Stevens turns up as the various men -- some 20 of them -- they encounter along the way. Ganesh, it seems, is the Hindu god of good fortune, who also puts in an appearance. The director is John Tillinger, who has staged such successful McNally dramas as "Lips Together, Teeth Apart" and "The Lisbon Traviata." Currently in previews; opens June 27. Manhattan Theater Club at City Center, Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan. Performances (through Aug. 22.): Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M.; Saturdays, 2:30 and 8 P.M.; Sundays, 2:30 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $35. Information: (212) 581-1212.   "ORESTES." En Garde Arts, which scouts the city for unusual locations for its dramas, has settled on the Penn Yards, at 59th Street and 12th Avenue in Manhattan, for its next production, a contemporary retelling of Euripides's "Orestes," written by Charles L. Mee and directed by Tina Landau. Kyle Chepulis is listed as the set designer, but the Hudson River, the New Jersey skyline and two twisted metal piers also figure prominently in the scenery. Previews begin June 22. Opens June 27. Performances: Tuesdays through Sundays at 8:30 P.M. Through July 18. Tickets: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, $15; Fridays and Saturdays, $17.50. Information: (212) 274-8123.   July    "MEASURE FOR MEASURE." Something's rotten in Vienna, so the Duke, played by Kevin Kline, goes underground to see if he can find out just what it is. The opening production of the 37th season of free Shakespeare in Central Park is to be directed by Michael Rudman, who has transposed the action to an island in the Caribbean. The cast includes Andre Braugher, Lisa Gay Hamilton and Blair Underwood. July 1 to 25. Delacorte Theater, Central Park, entrance at Central Park West and 81st Street. Performances: Tuesdays through Sundays, 8 P.M.; Free. Tickets are distributed at 6:15 the night of the performance; early arrival is recommended. Information: (212) 861-7277.   August    "IN THE SUMMER HOUSE." Jane Bowles's 1953 drama about a group of maladjusted Southern Californians and their efforts to evade reality was once described by Tennessee Williams as "the most original play I have ever read." This will be the first directorial undertaking of Joanne Akalaitis since she was abruptly deposed last spring as the artistic director of the Joseph Papp Public Theater. Philip Glass is composing new music for the play, and George Tsypin is designing the scenery. Previews begin July 8; opens Aug. 1. Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center. Performances: Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $30 and $37.50. Information: (212) 239-6200.   "ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL." After marrying Helena, Bertram decides that "a young man married is a man that's marred" and bolts for the wars. Helena chases after him. All manner of complications ensue before the two finally settle down. The British director Richard Jones, who staged "La Bete" on Broadway a few seasons ago, will bring his distinctive eye to bear on the Shakespearean comedy. Aug. 5 to 29. Delacorte Theater, Central Park, entrance at Central Park West and 81st Street. Performances: Tuesdays through Sundays, 8 P.M. Free. Tickets are distributed at 6:15 the night of the performance; early arrival is recommended. Information: (212) 861-7277.   "ANNIE WARBUCKS." The on-again, off-again sequel to "Annie" is on again, although the story has been through so many incarnations, who knows what lies in store for the famous redhead and onetime orphan, now living in the lap of Daddy Warbucks's luxury? You've got to hand it to the director and lyricist Martin Charnin, the composer Charles Strouse and the book writer Thomas Meehan: they don't give up. Harve Presnell is playing Daddy and Donna McKechnie will be his secretary, Grace. Annie hasn't been announced yet, but several young actresses grew too old for the part while waiting for this troubled musical to happen. Previews begin July 6; opens Aug. 9. Variety Arts Theater, 110 Third Avenue, at 13th Street, East Village. Performances: Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2:30 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3:30. Tickets: Sundays through Thursdays, $35 and $40; Fridays and Saturdays, $40 and $45. Information: (212) 239-6200.   "BLACK COMEDY" and "THE WHITE LIARS." Nancy Marchand is to star in this revival of two one-act plays by Peter Shaffer, first presented on Broadway in 1967. The latter piece, the curtain-raiser, involves a young man and a fraudulent fortuneteller. The former is about a sculptor, hoping to exhibit his wares to a wealthy buyer, until the lights in his apartment go out. Mr. Shaffer's trick is to reverse light and dark. When the electricity is on, the stage is dark. When it goes off, the stage lights come up, allowing the audience to observe a variety of characters stumbling over one another and the furniture. Gerald Gutierrez directs. Previews begin Aug. 10; opens Aug. 26; closes Oct. 10. Roundabout Theater Company at the Criterion Center, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street, Manhattan. Performances: Tuedays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 2 P.M. Tickets: $38 and $42. Information: (212) 869-8400.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ingrid Simon, Christopher Innes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ingrid Paige Simon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel K. Simon of New York, was married last evening to Christopher John Innes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Innes of Thousand Oaks, Calif. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Room.   Mrs. Innes, 22, is a vice president of a transportation-management consulting company owned by her mother, Barbara S. Simon Inc. in New York. Her father is a senior partner at Serko & Simon, a law firm in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mia Rhee and Daniel Kim
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mia Haeyoung Rhee, the daughter of Dr. Chong Heon Rhee of Easton, Conn., and the late Youngsil Rhee, was married yesterday to Daniel Dae Hyun Kim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Doo Tae Kim of Easton, Pa. The Rev. Louis Lunardini, an Episcopal minister, officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Ki Chun Lee, also an Episcopal minister, participated.

nytimes_articles.headline: Colleen Cowan And Patrick Dealy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Colleen Cowan, a daughter of Carol Cowan of Tucson, Ariz., and the late John Cowan, was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Dealy, a son of Jane Dealy of Chevy Chase, Md., and Francis X. Dealy Jr. of London. The Rev. Mary Cushman performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. James' Church in New York.   Mrs. Dealy, 30, is an actress in New York. She graduated from Randolph-Macon Woman's College in Lynchburg, Va. Her father was the president of Clowe & Cowan Inc., an industrial-supply company in Amarillo, Tex.

nytimes_articles.headline: Blame Doesn't Belong to Ewing
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   As a longtime fan and season ticket-holder of the New York Knicks, I naturally was deeply disappointed by the team's playoff elimination at the hands of the Chicago Bulls. But what was perhaps most distressing was the unfair blame leveled at Patrick Ewing for the Knicks' demise, as exemplified by George Vecsey's column written after Game 5. ("The Knicks may have gone as far as they could go. . . . No coach, not even Pat Riley, has been able to turn Patrick Ewing into a charismatic, gimme-the-ball leader," June 4.)

nytimes_articles.headline: A Harvest Of Advice
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S usually around this time of year, when the weeds are leaping and the carrots need thinning and the raspberry plants (given to me two springs ago) are still in the same spot where I "heeled them in" and the African lilies probably won't bloom because I didn't bring them out of the cellar until last month and the horseradish roots (they arrived in March) are still in the refrigerator where, the label said, I could store them "for a few days," that I think to myself, I hate gardening.   Everyone else is waltzing around saying, "Whoopee, look at my perfect perennial bed." Or sipping Champagne at the very garden gala where I promised myself I'd be, catching up on garden gossip. Or strolling down some 16th-century cypress alley somewhere, like the Villa d'Este in Italy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Streetscapes column on page 8 of the Real Estate section today misstates the location of a railroad boiler house that once served Grand Central Terminal. It was on the north side of 49th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brown Eight Makes It a Triple Play
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Brown men's varsity won the Herschede Cup, the top prize at the National Collegiate Rowing Championships here this afternoon, and thus captured rowing's triple crown, becoming the first eight ever to accomplish that feat.   As at the two other key events of the season, the Eastern Sprints and the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta, the Bears broke away from their foremost rival, Pennsylvania, this time prevailing over the Quakers by 2.83 seconds.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Creative Ferment Behind the Glass Boxes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Has the hour arrived for a manifesto? Is it time for a book to rouse architects from their recessionary torpor and chart a new course for their art? Twenty-seven years have passed since Robert Venturi's "Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture" outlined a program for post-modernism. Meanwhile, a new generation of architects, born after World War II, has edged onto the stage. Where is the document that declares what they stand for?   "Architecture Culture: 1943-1968" will have to do until the real thing comes along. The book, just published, is hardly a rabble-rousing tract. As its starchy title makes plain, this is a scholarly work: a "documentary anthology" of writings by architects and critics, selected and annotated with great intelligence and care by Joan Ockman, 40, a professor at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, Preservation and Planning, co-publishers of the book with Rizzoli. Still, the book carries a sly but potent ideological charge. Robert Venturi called his book a "gentle manifesto." Ms. Ockman has produced a crypto-manifesto: a smart, gutsy polemic in prim academic wrappers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Travels So Ordinary, Images So Rare
nytimes_articles.abstract: "ORDINARY events often best convey the true spirit of a trip."   This line appears in the first pages of "Focus on Travel" (Abbeville Press, $45), a new book by Allen Rokach, a photographer, and Anne Millman, a photography and science writer. In fact, one of the book's main messages is that the ordinary can be dramatic when captured on film.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chiefs Add Two Stars and 5 Rings
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the crazy mathematics of the National Football League, part of it due to free agency, the Kansas City Chiefs have come up with their own equation for possible success. It goes something like this: 4 + 1 = 1.   By teaming quarterback Joe Montana, who came to the Chiefs in a trade with San Francisco and has four Super Bowl rings, with running back Marcus Allen, who signed last week as a free agent from the Los Angeles Raiders and has one Super Bowl ring, in the same backfield, Kansas City hopes to get a Super Bowl championship.

nytimes_articles.headline: Putting an Old Saw to Work in the South
nytimes_articles.abstract: Here in this riverside city of 10,000, where gracious mansions were seized early in the Civil War by Union forces, a new invader has stormed the town. As before, the draw is real estate.   With its picturesque harbor, quaint downtown and elegant homes, Beaufort (pronounced BYEW-furt) has become a favored location for moviemakers. While one production company was filming in a rural area outside town at the end of May, Paramount was scouring the city with a real estate broker, looking for just the right house.

nytimes_articles.headline: French Movies Offer Tickets To Controversy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nowhere in the world are films still taken as seriously as they are in Paris. Old films, new films, dreadful films and sublime films. In any week, nearly 300 different movies are available in theaters that vary in size and decor from the big and the grand to the minuscule and the barely functional. On one recent Saturday afternoon I watched the first-run "Petain" in a 28-seat theater at the complex called the 7 Parnassiens. There were five other people in the house. (Showing at adjoining theaters in the same complex: "Indecent Proposal," "The Crying Game," "Singles," "Toys" and "Enchanted April.") Moviegoing of such intimacy becomes something akin to group therapy.   Only in Paris, too, could there be the kind of controversy that now surrounds "Francois Truffaut: Portraits Voles" ("Francois Truffaut: Stolen Portraits"), a fascinating, very good (if incomplete) new feature-length documentary about the life and work of the artist who, when he was alive, was often dismissed as being too bourgeois. The man whom his detractors thought to be too nice, too gentle, too eager to please, is now revealed to have been a rat.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the End, Distortion Triumphed Over Lani Guinier's Writings
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Prof. Carol Swain's "Black-Majority Districts: A Bad Idea" (Op-Ed, June 3) criticizes race-conscious districting, the policy of promoting the representation of the interests of black Americans by establishing electoral districts with black majorities. According to Professor Swain, African-Americans "cannot benefit from the continued emphasis on segregating black voters in black majority districts." She says she disagrees here with Prof. Lani Guinier, the former nominee to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kirsten Johnston, Piers C. A. Barker
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kirsten Anne Johnston, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brownell Johnston of Huntington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Piers Christopher Andrew Barker, a son of Drs. John and Rosalind Barker of Lakefield, Ontario, Canada. The Rev. John Jurik performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Lutheran Church.   Mrs. Barker, 22, is a financial consultant at Andersen Consulting in New York. She graduated from Cornell University, as did her husband. Her father is a tax partner with Arthur Andersen, a tax and accounting firm in New York, and an associate professor of taxation at New York University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suspects' Haste a Puzzle in Kuwait Trial
nytimes_articles.abstract: As Kuwait presents its case against 14 men being tried in what authorities say was a plot to kill former President George Bush, local officials and Western diplomats say the evidence has only strengthened their view that Iraq provided the explosives-laden jeep that the defendants are accused of taking into the country.   But the bumbling of the ring accused of planning the remote-control bombing in April -- including their failure to receive much help from supposed associates in Kuwait and their rush to abandon the explosives and hurry back to Iraq before their mission had been completed -- has puzzled many people who watched the initial day of testimony on June 5.

nytimes_articles.headline: Helen Tsai, Howard Boey
nytimes_articles.abstract: Helen Jeng-Chyi Tsai, a research analyst, was married yesterday to Dr. Howard Patrick Boey, a physician. The Rev. Karl Johnson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Neighborhood Church in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif.   Mrs. Boey works for Cambridge Systematics Inc., a technology and transportation consulting company in Cambridge, Mass. She graduated from Smith College and received a master's degree in city planning from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Shin L. Tsai of Palos Verdes Estates.

nytimes_articles.headline: Results Plus
nytimes_articles.abstract: TENNIS Stich to Face Doubles Partner in Final Wayne Ferreira, the defending champion, toppled Todd Martin, 6-7 (2-7), 6-3, 7-5, in the semifinals of the Queen's Club grass court tournament yesterday in London to set up a showdown with his doubles partner, Michael Stich. Stich saved four match points before beating the Australian Jamie Morgan, 5-7, 6-4, 8-6. Stich struggled for 2 hours 8 minutes to beat the 83d-ranked Morgan, an upset winner over Stefan Edberg on Friday in another three-set battle. Ferreira had problems handling Martin's consistent serve until midway through the match. He also was overpowered in the first-set tie breaker as the American moved smoothly into a 5-1 lead. The South African pounced on Martin's errors to tie the match by winning the second set and broke for a 6-5 lead in the third with rain starting to fall. He clinched a place in the final of the Stella Artois championship when Martin netted a service return. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball American League  MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Assigned Wayne Housie, outfielder, to New Orleans of the American Association. National League

nytimes_articles.headline: The Heroism Of Anonymous Men and Women
nytimes_articles.abstract: Documentary photographers are many but their jobs are few. In America, at least, photojournalists with long lists of awards to their names have trouble finding assignments, especially assignments that deal with difficult and depressing subjects. It may be that television news is so full of harrowing events that magazines are putting their money on reassurance. People can get bad news and appeals for pity for free; why would they pay extra at the newsstands? At all events, in a field where some sort of mass venue is essential, many "concerned photographers" find themselves playing to small audiences, devising projects primarily for books, or shifting into the business of celebrity portraiture.   Sebastiao Salgado is an exception. Not only has he been showered with awards, he has also been lionized by museums and widely published in the last few years. In 1991, his work seemed to be everywhere. This is a testament in part to his talent, which is undeniable and impressive, in part to the importance of his subjects and his evident sympathy for them, and in part to a comfortingly old-fashioned esthetic and belief in the goodness of humanity and its capacity to survive. Even his photographs of famine in the Sahel, the drought-plagued region south of the Sahara, generally played up the dignity, the classical grace and resignation of the starving rather than the horrors of their plight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lisa Johannessen and Robert Hoak Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Ann Johannessen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Johannessen of Grantham, N.H., was married yesterday to Robert Paul Hoak Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoak of Miami. The Rev. Richard Ringenwald performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, Vt.

nytimes_articles.headline: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions; A Park Ave. Boiler House and a Pair of Town Houses
nytimes_articles.abstract: This is another in a series of columns answering questions from readers about New York's changing streetscapes. 4-6 East 68th Street   Q. We have an unidentified, undated photograph album showing a pair of, presumably, New York town houses for which we think Herter Brothers was the interior decorator. Can you tell us the location and anything else about the buildings? . . . Alice Cooney Frelinghuysen, associate curator, Department of American Decorative Arts, Metropolitan Museum of Art.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chicago U. Graduates Hear About Diversity
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ralph W. Nicholas, the William Rainey Harper Professor in Anthropology at the University of Chicago, told graduates at the university's 101st commencement that introducing multicultural perspectives in education was helpful but in many instances had been abused.   "Such distinctions can feed our curiosities and provide great delight in discovery," Professor Nicholas said. "Unfortunately they are given exaggerated significance and made the basis for spurious claims of priority and superiority."

nytimes_articles.headline: Why Not More Safety In Car Inspections?
nytimes_articles.abstract: I read with interest your May 23d article about Connecticut's success in selling special interest license plates. Fine! But there is another side of our Department of Motor Vehicle activity which is woefully inadequate: car inspections.   Connecticut does test annually for emissions. But there is no mandatory testing for lights or brakes. I talked to my representative and senator about this and was told to contact Commissioner Goldberg. His reply to me was that nothing could be changed without an act of the legislature.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mondo Michael
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE name next to the buzzer in the hall says it all: Michael. Just Michael. Someone (not Michael) buzzes you in and directs you to a fifth-floor walk-up where Michael lives and publishes a hip, downtown magazine called U.   U is not about you. Him, maybe.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Museum Finds Its Time
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fashion seems to have caught up with the Jewish Museum, again. For a while, during the mid-1960's, it outshone the Modern and the Whitney and the Guggenheim as the New York institution most committed to the cutting edge in art, organizing exhibitions of up-and-comers like Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns and Kenneth Noland, and the show credited with launching Minimalism, "Primary Structures."   Then its trustees decided to turn away from a program that had little or nothing to do with Jews and Judaism. When the director of the museum, Sam Hunter, resigned in 1967, he cited as the cause of his discontent the "increasing emphasis on Judaica at the expense of contemporary art." Thereafter the museum, while becoming more central to the Jewish community, often seemed like a backwater in the bustling New York art scene; for many in the art world, it virtually ceased to exist.   But now, when widening ethnic rifts shape urban politics and multiculturalism dominates intellectual debate, the institution's emphasis on ethnic identity and social history has become downright trendy. The museum that reopens today in expanded quarters in the French Gothic Warburg mansion on upper Fifth Avenue, its home since 1947, seems almost perfectly in step with the latest multicultural theories.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
OTTOLINE MORRELL
Life on the Grand Scale.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: Coventry;
Mementos of a Revolutionary War Hero
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FEW spectators were about when late on the morning of Sept. 22, 1776, Nathan Hale was led by the British to what was then known as Artillery Park in New York, and to his fate, the gallows.

As history has it, it was there that Hale, just 21 and an officer and spy for the Continental Army, uttered the words that have become synonymous with patriotism: "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country."

nytimes_articles.headline: Maria Ritter, Chip Farnham
nytimes_articles.abstract: Maria Ritter and Joseph Farnham love cats, the ocean, flowers that grow by the sea, skinny-dipping, full moons, books and Cajun music, all of which they playfully incorporated into their June 5 wedding.   They met 15 years ago as students at the Gunnery, a boarding school in Washington, Conn. "We were always getting yelled at for P.D.A. -- public display of affection," the bride recalled.

nytimes_articles.headline: Anne Palmer, Stephen Laney Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anne Winslow Palmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Morgan Palmer Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Stephen Michael Laney Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laney of Marietta, Ga. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: United Way Reports 10 Percent Drop
nytimes_articles.abstract: CITING an uncertain economy, a smaller pool of donors and questions of staff misconduct, the United Way of Westchester and Putnam reported this month that contributions for the current fiscal year fell 10 percent short of expectations.   As a result, officials of organizations receiving money from United Way, an umbrella group that collects money for various charities, say they may now have to cut staff and possibly programs and turn to other fund-raising efforts to meet their budgets.

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: Long Island;
Adapting Space in a Slow Office Market
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ON a one-acre site on Veterans Memorial Highway in Islandia, a 10,250-square-foot one-story building built in 1990 for offices is being transformed into a day-care center called Tutor Time, which expects to open June 21.

In Garden City, 110,000 square feet of a 330,000-square-foot office building at 711 Stewart Avenue, once occupied in part by Computer Associates International, is being turned into retail space that will be leased out to about 550 merchants. The first, 55,000-square-foot phase of Megamarket, as the retail center is called, opened yesterday almost fully rented to 300 merchants.

nytimes_articles.headline: Neighbors Back Duck Farms, Not Condos
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TURNING south from Montauk Highway onto Bay Avenue in East Moriches, drivers see mostly duck farms along the Terrell River on the eastern side of the street and one-family houses on the western side.

The oldest house is the Abner Reeve House, circa 1700. Another, the Ann Smith House, was built before 1858 and is described by the Moriches Bay Historical Society as "a rare survivor of a once typical Long Island house type."

nytimes_articles.headline: Tara Mendrzycki and Adam M. Smith
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tara Ann Mendrzycki, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Mendrzycki of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Adam Mason Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Smith of Cranford, N.J. Msgr. James Connolly officiated at the Church of St. Joseph's.   Mrs. Mendrzycki Smith, 26, is a counselor in Mamaroneck, N.Y., with the drug abuse prevention program of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. She graduated from Duke University and received a master's degree in counseling from Columbia University. Her father is a partner at the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. Her mother, Catherine Mendrzycki, is the principal of St. Patrick's School, a parochial elementary school in Bedford, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: Street Crackdown's Aim: Turn Down That Stereo!
nytimes_articles.abstract: Car alarms, barking dogs, garbage trucks, jackhammers. These noises, which echo in the canyons of New York at all hours of the day and night, give added meaning to the phrase, "The city that never sleeps."   But this weekend, residents of at least one neighborhood may be finding it a little easier to get some rest. On Friday night, the police cracked down on one of the most irritating sources of noise, confiscating 19 cars with stereo "boom boxes" from the noisy streets of Washington Heights.

nytimes_articles.headline:
TRAVEL ADVISORY;
4 Museums Near Mexico City
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Within the last year, four museums have opened in Toluca, the capital of Mexico state, about an hour, depending on traffic, from downtown Mexico City. 

They are all in restored 19th-century town houses and, taken together, make an excellent day trip from the capital.

The museums are all within a radius of a few downtown blocks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Arianne Faber, Florian Kolb
nytimes_articles.abstract: Arianne Louise Faber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karlheinz Faber of Harrington Park, N.J., and Vienna, was married yesterday to Florian Christopher Kolb, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Karl-Heinz Kolb of Holzhausen, Germany. The Rev. Edward Duffy performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at O'Byrne Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.   Mrs. Kolb is a curatorial assistant at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif. She graduated from Middlebury College and received a master's degree in art history from the Courtauld Institute of Art in London. Her father is the senior vice president of Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc. in Montvale, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Some Tough Guys Who Also Sew Nicely
nytimes_articles.abstract:
EARLY in the day, in a room with a view of picnic tables and coils of barbed wire, 22 men in jeans and sweatshirts stood listening to a woman in a blue apron tell them about crack babies and babies with AIDS and about how to make quilts to give to these babies.

Two hours later, the men were laughing and talking as they waited their turn at six sewing machines. Twenty-two quilts, with prints of teddy bears or clowns or animals, were taking shape at the Enfield Correctional Institution, and by late afternoon they would be finished.

nytimes_articles.headline: SURFACING
nytimes_articles.abstract: HOME -- Don't-do-it-yourselfers: This new breed of tradesman, whose specialty is assembling "do it yourself" furniture (a la Ikea and Home Depot) and electronic equipment, has become as essential to unhandy homeowners as plumbers and electricians. LOOKS -- The hairless man: Hairlessness, from head to toe, may be emerging as the look of choice, given the prominence of Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley as style icons, as well as the latest batch of Calvin Klein models, with hardly a body hair -- chest, leg or otherwise -- among them. MUSIC -- "Grunge Lite": This compilation from C/Z Records, due out next month, is nothing short of grunge's death knell. It features Muzak-esque versions of songs by Nirvana and other grunge groups.

nytimes_articles.headline: Preachers of the Bar
nytimes_articles.abstract:
By my eighth birthday, I had been to more tent meetings than there were persimmon trees in Jefferson County, Ky. These were sweltering, midsummer bouts with faith, during which traveling preachers whipped our souls with feel-bad and feel-good speechifying. 

I recall those evangelical evenings now as I look back on my two years at the City University Law School. Here I have found the same unwavering faith and the same words spoken again and again -- oppression for sin, reactionary for backslider, empowerment for salvation -- the same belief in the magical power of words.

nytimes_articles.headline: Helen Hayes Tribute
nytimes_articles.abstract: A memorial tribute to the actress Helen Hayes, who died on March 17, is to be held at 12:30 P.M. on Friday at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. James MacArthur, Miss Hayes's son, will be the host. Among those scheduled to participate are Barbara Cook, Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Julie Harris, Richard Kiley, Burgess Meredith, Jason Robards, Sylvia Sidney and Fritz Weaver. Leslie Browne and Robert La Fosse of American Ballet Theater will perform a dance elegy. Public seating will be first come first served.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
FAMILY PORTRAIT
THE FORMS OF WATER
By Andrea Barrett.
Pocket Books, $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kathryn J. Beeby, Louis J. Scenti
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kathryn Jean Beeby, a daughter of Shelley and Kenneth Beeby of Duxbury, Mass., was married there yesterday to Louis John Scenti, the son of Isabel Scenti of Cranston, R.I., and the late Louis J. Scenti. The Revs. Lewis and Joy Mills, Episcopal priests, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.   Ms. Beeby, 31, is keeping her name. She is the executive assistant and the chief of staff to the Commissioner of the New York City Sanitation Department. She graduated from New York University and received a master's degree in public policy from the New School for Social Research. Her father is a vice president and the chief legal counsel at Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. in Lakeville, Mass.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Jazz Festival and Its Musical Muses; Gerry Mulligan -- This 'Big Fat Boy' Has a Generous Spirit
nytimes_articles.abstract: The 1993 JVC Jazz Festival, which runs from Friday to June 26, will be sleeker than in previous years. With 20 concerts at six locations throughout Manhattan, the schedule is heavy in singers and tributes (to the likes of Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker). And because of rising costs, many smaller events, like the afternoon piano concerts, have been dropped. But despite the leanness, the festival should still offer performances to satisfy the tastes of most jazz lovers. Here, six noted authors tell why a performer or honoree on this year's program speaks to them.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: MATCHBOX CONVENTION   Forty years ago, Jack Odell created a brass prototype of a small Road Roller and put it in a matchbox-sized container so his daughter could take it with her to school. It was the genesis of Matchbox Originals, which have become collectors' items and will be celebrated at a convention today in Iselin.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fittipaldi Is Driven By More Than Racing
nytimes_articles.abstract: If any two drivers spanned the spectrum of motor racing in May at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, those two were Emerson Fittipaldi and Bobby Rahal.   Fittipaldi used an alert late-race restart to win his second Indianapolis 500, while Rahal was bumped from the lineup with a few minutes left in qualifying and missed his first Indy 500 since he started coming there in 1982.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ms. Smith, Mr. VanDenburgh
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stacey Louise Smith, a daughter of Larry and Dorothea Smith of Irvington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Arnold James VanDenburgh, the son of Esther Hastings VanDenburgh of Canton, Mass., and the late Arnold H. VanDenburgh. The Rev. Carla Forrest, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the summer home of the bride's parents on Block Island, R. I.   Mrs. VanDenburgh, 30, is the archivist and a woodworker for Albert Paley, a metal sculptor in Rochester. She graduated from Smith College and received a master's degree in woodworking and furniture design from the Rochester Institute of Technology. Her father is the managing editor of Parade magazine in New York. Her mother is the business editor of The Rockland Journal News, a newspaper in West Nyack, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'The Hyphen of Passion Between Shilly and Shally'
nytimes_articles.abstract: DREAM OF FAIR TO MIDDLING WOMEN By Samuel Beckett. Edited by Eoin O'Brien and Edith Fournier. 241 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing in association with Riverrun Press.

nytimes_articles.headline: Charlie Rose Never Runs Out Of Things to Say
nytimes_articles.abstract: This is the Charlie Rose story that has been making the rounds: The tall, droopy-eyed talk show host had just left Sylvia's, the barbecue-belt outpost in Harlem. Shambling down the sidewalk after lunch, he was stopped by a street vendor in sneakers and a backwards baseball cap who had some advice: "Sometimes you need to let the guests talk."   Mr. Rose has heard that before. "I know I interrupt too much," he says. Even Mike Wallace of "60 Minutes," a fan of Mr. Rose's, says there are moments when "I want to shout at the screen, 'Shut up, Charlie!' "

nytimes_articles.headline: Strolling a New England Isle
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR a brief moment last August Cuttyhunk Island made the news. The quickest way to describe the location of the newly named Queen's Bottom reef off Massachusetts where the QE2 ran aground is to say that it lies halfway between this little-known island and Martha's Vineyard.    By the time my wife, Susan, and I headed out to Cuttyhunk on our annual visit late in September, the island had returned to its somnolence. In history texts, the first English settlement in New England, established by Bartholomew Gosnold and his band of pioneers on Cuttyhunk in 1602, occasionally receives a brief footnote. But Gosnold's major mark on history was made when he anchored "near a great cape, where in five or six hours we had pestered our ship so with codfish that we threw numbers of them overboard again . . . wherefore we named the place 'Cape Cod.' "

nytimes_articles.headline: Saratoga
nytimes_articles.abstract: Unlike the Queen of England, who presides annually at Royal Ascot, modern Presidents of the United States do not frequent the track. Over the years, though, many Presidential families have visited Saratoga Springs, whose race track was called America's Ascot when it opened more than a century ago. And they have discovered this resort's habit, even as it evokes the old, of anointing the new.    As Abraham Lincoln pondered the siege of Petersburg, his son Bob came to Saratoga to celebrate his graduation from Harvard and found this ancient oasis agog over a new race course. Plans were afoot to create the country's finest carriage road, to be decorated with Victorian "cottages," many of which sparkle on today's six-lane Union Avenue. Union Hall, where he stayed, became the Grand Union, one of the largest hotels in the world. (It was torn down several decades ago.)

nytimes_articles.headline: In the End, Distortion Triumphed Over Lani Guinier's Writings; Seeking Compromise
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Lani Guinier is a fine scholar with the courage to follow an argument to the limit of its logic. That very disposition made her an unwise choice to head the agency responsible for shaping and enforcing civil rights policy.

nytimes_articles.headline: 14 Can Compete Again
nytimes_articles.abstract: SCOTT HAMILTON, BRIAN BOITANO and VIKTOR PETRENKO, the last three Olympic men's figure skating champions, are among 14 professional skaters cleared to resume international competition, including next year's Winter Games. The reinstatements by the International Skating Union were decided upon during the council's meeting in Wurzberg, Germany. Each skater had previously been reinstated by his own country's national governing body.

nytimes_articles.headline: Why Minorities Need Special Help
nytimes_articles.abstract: Recently the media has highlighted the position of some people that racially and ethnically defined programs deprive them of benefits. The article on the Legal Education Access Program at Touro College  [ "L.I. Law Schools Aim for 'Diversity' With New Intensity," May 16 ]  included a comment by a white male that the program "gives an academic advantage to minorities." We are struggling with our complex reactions to this contention.    We are fully aware that many whites were victimized by prejudice in the past. For example, earlier in this century Irish-American immigrants were confronted with signs posted by employers declaring, "Irish and Dos Need Not Apply." Further, people of all races are discriminated against on the basis of class, sexual preference, physical ability, weight and many other physical and psychological characteristics, most of which are beyond their control. These and all forms of oppression are atrocities which must be abolished.

nytimes_articles.headline: Using a Computer to Diagnose Illnesses
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONE afternoon a 37-year-old man showed up in the emergency room of a Connecticut hospital complaining of shortness of breath, a sense of impending doom and heart palpitations. He had been unable to work for a week because of extreme uneasiness. The attending doctor recommended he be transferred to a psychiatric hospital.   But the doctor was talked out of the transfer after he was asked a series of questions, not by another doctor but by a computer program called PsychPro. The program was developed by a New Haven company to use artificial intelligence to assess mental health problems and suggest treatment; in this case the patient was released with a prescription for Alprozolam, a drug for treating panic attacks.  Doctors' Suspicions    The developer of PsychPro, Dr. William M. Glazer, a professor of psychiatry at Yale, said that "doctors have been very suspicious of these kinds of things because they fear these computerized tools are going to control them, and take away their independence." He said that to some extent the fear was justified.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mary Stiles, Mandell Ourisman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary Martin Stiles and Mandell Jack Ourisman were married yesterday at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles. The Rev. David J. Ourisman, a Methodist minister and a son of Mr. Ourisman, performed the ceremony.   Mrs. Ourisman is a political consultant to the Republican Party in Washington. She graduated from the University of Texas. She is a daughter of Aleen Martin of Mexia, Tex., and the late Dr. Herbert Martin. Her previous marriage ended in divorce.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Campaign Bill Threatened   A campaign finance bill may die in the Senate if Democrats cannot win over a few Republicans by modifying provisions for public money. Page 30. U.N. Defied in Cambodia   Cambodian Government leaders, defeated in a U.N.-sponsored election, threatened secession by most of the eastern half of the country. Page 9. Microsoft Seeks Cable Deal   The software giant and two cable companies are creating a system to merge computing and TV. Page 31.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. SAYS ATTACK DEALT HEAVY BLOW TO SOMALI FACTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: United Nations officials say that a military force led by the United States destroyed arms depots, captured 200 Somalis and damaged a radio station in an assault early Saturday morning against a faction blamed for an attack last weekend in which 23 Pakistani peacekeepers were killed.   Early this morning, a second assault by American warplanes was staged against the headquarters of the faction's commander, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, who has been accused of ordering the ambush and of killing the 23 peacekeepers and wounding 59 others. General Aidid has denied responsibility for the ambush.

nytimes_articles.headline: Meredith Meiler, Andrew Rocca
nytimes_articles.abstract: Meredith Ann Meiler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mark J. Meiler of Oneonta, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Andrew Francis Rocca, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Rocca of West Chester, Pa. The Rev. Paul Roman performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary's Church.   Mrs. Rocca, 24, was until recently a trading assistant at Mitsui & Company in New York, an importer and exporter of paper products. She graduated from Franklin and Marshall College.

nytimes_articles.headline: Toyota Tries for the Light Fantastic
nytimes_articles.abstract: ACTUALLY, Isao Tsuzuki is more than just an engineer. He was in charge of the entire project when Toyota decided to create the fourth generation of its Supra sports car and to make it one of the hotter sets of wheels on anybody's road.   To that end, Tsuzuki's team reduced the new car's weight by 310 pounds, despite the addition of standard dual air bags, bigger wheels and tires, and a heavier antilock brake system.

nytimes_articles.headline: Memorabilia From Out of the Wild Blue Yonder
nytimes_articles.abstract: OTTO KALLIR, A COLLECTOR OF aeronautical material, was not discouraged back in 1907 when, at age 13, a letter he wrote to the Wright brothers went unanswered. Years later, as an art dealer in Manhattan, the Viennese native acquired 50 letters, photographs and documents signed by Wilbur and Orville Wright.    Kallir, who founded the Galerie St. Etienne in 1939 and was responsible for discovering Grandma Moses and introducing the paintings of the Austrian Expressionists Egon Schiele and Gustav Klimt to the United States, died in 1978. The Wright manuscripts are among 210 flight-related offerings from his estate that will be auctioned tomorrow at Sotheby's in New York. The holdings, which Sotheby's describes as the most comprehensive such collection to go on the block in 25 years, are expected to fetch about $800,000.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tryout for Dickerson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Los Angeles Raiders tailback ERIC DICKERSON, the second-leading rusher in National Football League history, will meet with and work out for Atlanta Falcons management and coaches tomorrow, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q and A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Civil War Battle Sites   Q. Are there any group tours specifically focused on Civil War battlefields in Pennsylvania and Virginia? -- Rosalind Hall, Douglaston, Queens.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shortsightedness
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Prejudice does die hard, as Suzanna Andrews makes clear. In discussing gender stereotypes, she dismisses two movies because the male leads, Danny DeVito and Al Pacino, are short and therefore have no credible romantic appeal. Either I've missed some fundamental point about prejudice, or she has. HALLIE BLACK Chicago

nytimes_articles.headline: Turnback the Alarm Gets Well Soon
nytimes_articles.abstract: Turnback the Alarm, who missed 10 months of racing after a severe injury last summer, continued to make long strides in her remarkable comeback yesterday when she won the $150,000 Hempstead Handicap at Belmont Park and anointed herself as one of the premiere fillies in the sport.   The 4-year-old gray, who is rapidly becoming a medical as well as a racing marvel, won her second Grade I stakes in three weeks as she outran a strong field of five rivals and, with a relentless move in the homestretch, beat Deputation to the wire by a length and a half. And in the duel for second place, Deputation edged You'd Be Surprised by a nose while nobody else came within 14 lengths of the leaders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Inspector Ends A Hunger Strike Against Agency
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Government scientist has ended his hunger strike against the National Institutes of Health in its 33d day, defusing at least for now an embarrassing confrontation over the institutes' handling of scientific fraud cases.   The scientist, Walter W. Stewart, began the strike after he and Dr. Ned Feder, both scientific fraud investigators, were criticized by Health and Human Services officials and their office was closed. On Friday he was told by a doctor that he was in danger of sudden, irregular heart rhythms and possibly death from heart failure if he continued his fast. He began eating later that night.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Jazz Festival and Its Musical Muses; Thelonious Monk -- A Propeller on a Skullcap That Spins With Quirky Energy
nytimes_articles.abstract: The 1993 JVC Jazz Festival, which runs from Friday to June 26, will be sleeker than in previous years. With 20 concerts at six locations throughout Manhattan, the schedule is heavy in singers and tributes (to the likes of Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker). And because of rising costs, many smaller events, like the afternoon piano concerts, have been dropped. But despite the leanness, the festival should still offer performances to satisfy the tastes of most jazz lovers. Here, six noted authors tell why a performer or honoree on this year's program speaks to them.

nytimes_articles.headline: Embargo on Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Representative Charles Rangel is right on the mark with his new bill to end our embargo on medicines and food for Cuba.

nytimes_articles.headline: Step by Step, the State Moves Toward Integration
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE new state legislation requiring all towns and cities to join regional discussions on achieving greater racial diversity in their public schools leaves much unstated because of the volatile politics of race.   To win passage in a reluctant General Assembly, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and his Education Commissioner, Vincent L. Ferrandino, had to strip references to race and integration from the legislation and express their intent in the all-purpose euphemism "diversity." Even diversity was left undefined, and no goals for achieving it were stated.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Open: Towns Brace For 30,000
nytimes_articles.abstract: TOMORROW, the deluge. With the start of practice rounds for the U.S. Open, an estimated 30,000 spectators will descend upon the Baltusrol Golf Club here.    For Springfield (population: 14,000) and its neighbors, Summit and Union, the weeklong championship will present a giant challenge in crowd control and a major economic opportunity.

nytimes_articles.headline: If You're Thinking of Living in: Long Beach
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN the 1920's, the City of Long Beach, built on a barrier island on the Atlantic Ocean, was a playground for the rich and famous, among them Florenz Ziegfeld, Clara Bow and Rudolph Valentino.

By the 1960's it had become rundown, its gone-to-seed hotels filled with patients released from mental institutions, welfare recipients and the elderly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aphrodite Spirocostas, Carlo Prinzo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Aphrodite Ann Spirocostas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Spirocostas of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Carlo Joseph Prinzo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Prinzo of Dix Hills, L.I. The Rev. Damaskinos Ganas performed the ceremony at Kimisis Theotokou Greek Orthodox Church in Brooklyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Out and Organized
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN big, loopy letters, Mary Hansen wrote the word "homosexual" on the blackboard, then turned to face the 25 unruly students in Anne Corey's ninth-grade humanities class at the High School of Telecommunications Arts and Technology in Brooklyn. "Who's the babe?" one boy asked. A few others hooted. Ms. Hansen, unfazed, asked them to divide into groups and make lists of words that came to mind when they thought about the one she had just finished writing. "And don't censor yourself," she said. "Seriously, we can handle it."   This was Ms. Hansen's ninth such "peer training" session -- designed to promote tolerance of homosexuals among straight teen-agers and to provide role models for gay ones. Her supervisor, David Nieves, who accompanied her, had led more than 100 peer trainings at other high schools and colleges. There wasn't much they had not seen before: students unwilling to touch the paper on which the words were written; others reduced to shrieks when the lists were read aloud. Ms. Hansen just smiled and copied their replies onto the board.

nytimes_articles.headline: Friend Arrested in Stabbing Death of 12-Year-Old
nytimes_articles.abstract: After an afternoon of bicycling and relay races down a quiet residential block in Brooklyn, Charles Mapp, 12, and his best friend joined other youths on the stoop of a brownstone apartment building, relaxing and enjoying the warm spring night.    But words between the two friends quickly turned loud and harsh on Friday, and eventually screams pierced the night as Charles lay on a sidewalk with a steak knife in his chest. He died 10 minutes later at Woodhull Medical Center.

nytimes_articles.headline: Best Books For the Shore, For Young And Old
nytimes_articles.abstract: THIS summer, some people may lug to the beach all 1,295 pages of Gore Vidal's collected essays, "United States," or Vikram Seth's 1,349-page novel, "A Suitable Boy." (They'd make a nearly balanced set of exercise weights.) It's a safe bet those people won't have children and their paraphernalia to lug along, too. A parent can carry only so much, and if you want to sink into a book while watching the kids, you'll need eyes all over your head.   One clever alternative that won't break your back is to take along books both adults and children can savor. These are not merely children's stories that adults will find inoffensive, but crossover works that grown-ups without children might want to read, too. The heroes range from Aladdin (the original version) to Max (a super-chic dog gone Hollywood). And the tales include two stunning versions of "Cinderella," one witty, one lyrical.

nytimes_articles.headline: Anne Gambrill, Warner James Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anne Elizabeth Gambrill, a daughter of Johanne N. Gambrill of Tenafly, N.J., and James H. Gambrill of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Warner Thompson James Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. James of Madison, Conn. The Rev. Brian Fidler performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J.    Mrs. James, 23, and her husband, 24, are teachers at the Trinity-Pawling School in Pawling, N.Y., she of history and he of English. They graduated from Bates College. The bride's father is an associate at the law firm of Crummy, Del, Deo, Dolan, Griffinger & Vecchione in Newark. Her mother teaches mathematics at the Dwight-Englewood School in Englewood.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
A Gallery Makes Its Debut
nytimes_articles.abstract:
"ART doesn't have a permanent zip code," Joseph Szoecs declares. He explains that art used to be centered in Rome, then Paris and later New York, so why not Jersey City? Mr. Szoecs has a five-year lease on a former machine shop he recently converted into the Trans Hudson Gallery, and he says that making Jersey City synonymous with the best in contemporary art is his goal. 

To carry out his vision, he has mounted as his first show a large and varied group exhibition called "Fusion." The title furthers what the gallery's name portends, that he is taking art from both sides of the river. The show is two-thirds New Jersey and one-third New York City, but precise numbers are not the point. Mr. Szoecs (pronounced search) notes that his artists come from many places -- Hungary, Sweden and California, for example -- and happen to live on either bank of the Hudson. (Mr. Szoecs himself is originally from Hungary.)

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Bonamo And Dr. Philbin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Katherine Mary Bonamo, the daughter of Katherine K. Bonamo of Westfield, N.J., and Dr. John J. Bonamo of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Michael Philbin Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Philbin of Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. Matthew D. Looney performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Holy Trinity Church in Westfield.   Mrs. Philbin, 26, is an associate research analyst, in Westport, Conn., with the Bases Group, a market-research company. She and her husband graduated summa cum laude from Yale University, where they were elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received a master's degree in linguistics from Brown University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Horrid Mets Can't Match Originals
nytimes_articles.abstract: WITH morbid fascination, I watched Pete Incaviglia of the Phillies hit a game-deciding three-run wallop all the way to Yonkers on Thursday and I could only think of Casey Stengel's phrase for mammoth home runs his pitchers allowed: "Over a building."   Then on Friday, two members of the Lenny Dykstra Chowder and Marching Society went out to Shea to watch Lenny scurry home with the winning run on an error. All I could think of was Casey's sympathy for fledgling Mets fans: "The attendance got trimmed again."

nytimes_articles.headline: Should We Revive the Dinosaurs?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Much as we hate to be drawn into the frenzied hype for Steven Spielberg's "Jurassic Park," it is hard to ignore a megabuck movie that has already become grist for museum displays, op-ed commentary, "Nightline" and lively debate among scientists. The film's central notion -- that arrogant, unscrupulous or unthinking scientists might bring long-extinct dinosaurs back to life -- has clearly struck a chord.   The faint of heart may rest assured that even the maddest of scientists will not have the capability any time soon of resurrecting the dinosaurs. The movie, like Michael Crichton's book on which it was based, hypothesizes that blood-sucking mosquitoes dined on the dinos, and immediately afterward got stuck in tree resin that later hardened to amber, preserving the mosquitoes and the dinosaur blood for tens of millions of years. Modern scientists are then able, in the movie, to extract the blood from the amber, isolate a fragment of dinosaur DNA, stick it into an egg, and presto -- out comes a new dinosaur.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Fitting Tribute to Nation's History
nytimes_articles.abstract: IF historical accounts are to be trusted, the process of any revolution is as much about bureaucratic wrangling as is it about fire-and-brimstone rebellion. The brave slogans and the colorful banners and flags waving in the wind are the foundations of popular myths.   In the French and American Revolutions, the rebels worried as much, if not more, about law and justice than about actual battles.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hikes Perched High in Madeira
nytimes_articles.abstract: LANDING on Madeira would be "fairly firm -- a positive arrival," our pilot warned. He braked the plane so hard that my head touched the seat in front. The Atlantic Ocean lapped at both ends of the single runway, which vaulted on tall cement pylons out over the water.   There used to be talk of moving Madeira's airport to its only significant flat space. But the island's western plateau, 5,000 feet high, is remote from its southeastern tourist centers and often in cloud. The narrow plateau and spiky, 6,000-foot mountains farther east form the spine of an island only 35 miles from northwest to southeast and 14 miles across. Cliffs up to 1,800 feet loom above an almost beachless coastline. Rivers have sliced narrow, deep valleys in the flanks of this remnant of long-extinct volcanoes some 350 miles west of Morocco.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Andrews, Mr. Murphy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Whitney Leigh Andrews, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Andrews of Middlebury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Paul Clarke Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew P. Murphy Jr. of Gibson Island, Md. The Rev. Dennis Calhoun officiated at the Middlebury Congregational Church. The Rev. John Regan, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.   Mrs. Murphy is a director of client services at Lifetime Learning Systems, an educational marketing company in New York. She and her husband graduated from the University of Virginia. Her father is the chairman of the Amdura Corporation in New York, a hardware manufacturer. He is a former chairman of the Singer Sewing Machine Corporation in Stamford, Conn.

nytimes_articles.headline: At Cliburn Competition, A Pianist's Recognition
nytimes_articles.abstract: HIS own modest hope was to "make a good impression," Andrew Armstrong said shortly before taking part in the recently concluded Ninth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Fort Worth, Tex.    But the 19-year-old pianist, the youngest of the 36 participants and one of only 6 Americans, did far better than that. He became one of 12 semifinalists, won the $4,000 Jury Discretionary Award and attracted the attention of Van Cliburn himself.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Blizzard
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: I just want to report a very good flight experience over the blizzard weekend March 13-14, and to compliment Finnair for its handling of the flight from Helsinki to New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Island's Theaters Look To a Revitalized Season
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN the Bay Street Theater Festival opened in Sag Harbor last July its founders knew that they wanted to "revitalize the theater experience on the Island."    Period.
