nytimes_articles.headline: Navratilova Will Play
nytimes_articles.abstract: After an embarrassing defeat by a qualifier this week at Edgbaston, England, MARTINA NAVRATILOVA has changed her mind and decided to return to Eastbourne for next week's grass-court tournament.

nytimes_articles.headline: Demons Within, Enemies Without
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The Presidency is obviously not in good shape. Part of the fault -- a large part -- is the incumbent's. But the rest of us also deserve blame. So before considering what Bill Clinton needs to do to help himself, I begin with what his countrymen can do to help him.

Most of all, he needs for us to give him breathing room -- the chance to develop and present proposals without having them instantly suffocated by the cynicism that has become de rigueur in the media and by the automatic opposition of Congressional Republicans.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: FICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: C.I.A. ADVENTURE BLUE HEARTS By Jim Lehrer. Random House, $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yum Yum
nytimes_articles.abstract: PIEKARSKI means "son of a baker" in Polish, and Chuck Piekarski, a strapping 39-year-old tenor with an Actors' Equity card, has been on staff baking desserts at night for God's Love We Deliver for more than two years. Last Tuesday around midnight, he was putting 50 trays into the convection ovens in a commercial kitchen on the Upper West Side. Six hundred people with AIDS in the metropolitan area would find his brownies included with their free, freshly cooked meals the next day. Some of them would find his miniature birthday cakes, as well.   "I'm sort of like Bigfoot around here because nobody sees me," Mr. Piekarski said with a shy, untheatrical smile as he lumbered in his baseball cap and chocolate-smeared apron around the kitchen, hauling buckets of sugar (his recipe calls for 33 3/4 cups), boxes of eggs (90) and semi-sweet chocolate (17 pounds). "It's a good dessert," he said, "but it's one of the messy ones."

nytimes_articles.headline: MUSIC: Pianist Builds a Career By Taking His Time
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE Swiss-born pianist Andreas Haefliger is one of a growing number of young musicians who have dared to say no to the competition scene and to build a career slowly and carefully, not accepting every engagement -- "the old-fashioned way," as he puts it.

 Mr. Haefliger, 30, has made a number of highly acclaimed international debuts recently, and he will give his first New Jersey performance next Sunday at 8:30 P.M. at the Cape May Music Festival. He will perform in the Congress Hall Hotel, and his program will include Sophia Gubaidulina's "Chacona," Schumann's "Davidsbundlertanze," Mozart's Sonata in F (K. 332), Debussy's "Images" Book 2 and Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz."

nytimes_articles.headline: For Some, Job Sharing Offers a Solution
nytimes_articles.abstract: SYNERGY -- defined by Webster as interaction so the total effect is greater than the sum of individual effects -- is taking place among employees in companies that allow two or more employees to share one full-time job.    This is the case with at least two Westchester companies, Nynex and Career Blazers, both in White Plains.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wendy Cramer, Andrew Sanford
nytimes_articles.abstract: Wendy Sue Cramer, a daughter of Susan Tofel of New York and Robert Cramer of Washington, was married yesterday to Andrew Beatty Sanford, a son of Elizabeth B. Boocock of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Richard C. Sanford of New York. The Rev. Jamie Hamilton, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.   Mrs. Sanford, 26, graduated from Duke University and received a master's degree in social work from Columbia University. Her father is the owner of Robert S. Cramer & Company, a public relations firm in Washington. Her mother, a former chairwoman of the board of the Nightingale-Bamford School, is a vice president of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, the nonprofit social service organization in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gilda Romanelli, Mark E. Haranzo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gilda Romanelli and Mark E. Haranzo, associates in the New York law firm of Putney, Twombly, Hall & Hirson, were married yesterday. Archbishop Renato R. Martino, the Papal Nuncio to the United Nations, performed the ceremony at St. Peter of Alcantara Church in Port Washington, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sangeeta Hingorani, Charles Birnbach
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Sangeeta Ram Hingorani, a daughter of Ram and Kamla Hingorani of Norwalk, Conn., was married last Thursday to Dr. Charles David Birnbach, the son of Richard and Lily Birnbach of Great Neck, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.   Dr. Hingorani, who is keeping her name, graduated from Yale University and received a medical degree from Yeshiva University. She is to begin a residency in pediatrics at Children's Hospital in Seattle later this month. Her father is the president of A & H Engineers, a civil engineering firm in New York. Her mother is the president of Quality Homes, a real estate company in Norwalk.

nytimes_articles.headline: Family Secrets
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE DAY
By Douglas Hobbie.
241 pp. New York: 
A John Macrae Book/
Henry Holt & Company. $22.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ann Browning, E. L. Packard
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ann Browning, a retired real-estate agent at Sulzberger-Rolfe Inc. in New York, was married on Monday to E. Lawrence Packard, a golf-course architect. The Rev. Ann Richards performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.   Mrs. Browning-Packard graduated from the University of Arizona. She is a daughter of Helen Browning of Belleair Bluffs, Fla., and the late Alfred O. Browning.

nytimes_articles.headline: Natalie Cole Steps Out Of Her Father's Shadow
nytimes_articles.abstract: Natalie Cole's new album, "Take a Look," should erase any lingering doubts that the 1991 blockbuster "Unforgettable With Love" was an inspired, one-of-kind stroke of pop nostalgia. Recorded with many of the same arrangers and players, the new album also focuses on jazz and pre-rock pop songs, many of them standards lavishly arranged for orchestra.    But if the sound of "Take a Look" (Elektra 9 61496; CD and cassette) is similar to that of "Unforgettable," a tribute to her father, Nat (King) Cole, its perspective is broader and quirkier. And it firmly establishes Ms. Cole as a polished pop-jazz stylist of conservative temperament who is a hybrid of her father, Ella Fitzgerald and the young Aretha Franklin.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lighten Up!
nytimes_articles.abstract: This week, buy a hammock. Plant all the annual flower seeds you thought it was too late to plant. I'm tossing in scarlet zinnias, lavatera, cosmos, lemon gem marigolds and spider flowers. They'll come into their own by late summer.   Then read the accompanying article and take a nap. Go see "Dave" or something even sillier. Do not buy a single garden book. Don't talk to any gardeners. They might give you a plant.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Computers Could Link Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract:
REGARDLESS of the outcome of a metropolitan Hartford school desegregation lawsuit, black, white and Hispanic children from the suburbs and the city may soon find themselves collaborating on homework assignments, talking back and forth computer to computer.

Connecticut's test project, using computers, telephone lines and video equipment so children can see one another, is expected to involve elementary school students from Morley School in West Hartford and Annie Fisher School in Hartford, two racially and economically different neighborhoods.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International 3-23  SOMALIA ATTACK HITS ARMS DEPOTS  A United Nations military force led by the United States destroyed arms depots and captured 200 Somalis in retaliation against a warlord blamed for an attack in which 23 peacekeepers were killed.  1  U.N. MANDATE IS EXPANDED  News analysis: In launching its Somalia strike, the United Nations has expanded its peacekeeping mandate while raising the issue of whether U.N. efforts must always depend on U.S. firepower.  16

nytimes_articles.headline: Your Home: Mitchell-Lama; Desirable And Now, Available
nytimes_articles.abstract: AMONG the most desirable housing built in New York City for moderate-income families between in the 1960's and early 1970's were its 151,000 Mitchell-Lama apartments. Some had spectacular views over the Hudson or East River, others were at the oceanfront or within walking distance of Lincoln Center or Greenwich Village.   Constructed with heavy subsidies from municipal and state sources and blessed with tax breaks, they provided thousands of families with an attractive apartment at a relatively low and stable cost, either as a rental or a co-op with a nominal share price.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Teen-Agers Care for the Elderly
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AT the parallel bars, Joseph Katz, who is in his 80's, was doing an improvised but inspired little dance routine in the sunny physical education area of the Jewish Geriatric Home here. He had decided that the assigned exercise -- raising and lowering one leg at a time -- was far less fun than his own invention.

"Come on, now, Joe -- one, two, up and down," urged Tyler Porter, his 20-year-old guide for the morning exercise session and a model of patience and good humor. "You can do it."

nytimes_articles.headline: Bullying Is Not Leading
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   James Oestreich states that "as in every other area of music, the balance between control and freedom is intricate and delicate." This observation has direct bearing on the discussion in the article "Playing (and Singing) Politics" in the same issue. Composers who use art as a bully pulpit, insisting on a narrow interpretation, ignore that delicate balance between freedom and control. By its very nature, music is an art of multiple meanings. And in music, as in most areas of life, we learn best by example. By this I mean that we are moved by lessons of the heart, communicated with a generosity of spirit. Thus, we are led rather than subdued.  MARY L. SENN Rome, N. Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: Carol A. Clark, Robert J. Fucigna
nytimes_articles.abstract: Drs. Carol Ann Clark and Robert Joseph Fucigna were married yesterday in Bayonne, N.J. Msgrs. John Fagan and Emmet Fagan, uncles of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Vincent de Paul Church.   Mrs. Fucigna is a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. She graduated from Chestnut Hill College. She and her husband received medical degrees from the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, in Newark. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Clark of Bayonne.

nytimes_articles.headline: Not Even Doc Can Revive Mets This Time
nytimes_articles.abstract: One would think that the Mets had exhausted all possible methods of defeat. They've lost on ninth-inning errors and offensive collapses, blown rundown plays and horribly squandered saves.    Never before, though, during this dismal season had the Mets found themselves in this ugly situation: Last night at Shea Stadium, they could not manage a single run. So with the best team in baseball against him -- and one of the worst at his back -- even Doc Gooden couldn't save the woeful Mets this time.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Far-Reaching Resonance
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your story on "Children of Fate: Life and Death in a Sicilian Family"  [ "Reaching Back for Images of a Family Scarred by Life," May 23 ]  points out that it won the prize for best documentary at the Sundance festival. It should also be noted that the film captured a Silver Centaur, just behind the Gold, at the Third Petersburg International Documentary festival in February. I attended that festival and was struck, as were many others, at the Russians bringing off the event at all, what with their assorted economic and other ailments.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Westchester Q&A;: Capricia D. McClellan;
Getting Help in the Job of Being a Parent
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JEAN HARRIS will be in Yonkers Friday talking about something close to her heart -- the need to teach parenting skills to low-income mothers. As a prisoner at Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for the murder of the Scarsdale Diet doctor, Dr. Herman Tarnower, Ms. Harris had worked to help other inmates learn how to be good mothers.

This time her audience will be graduates of A Different Start, a parent-child educational program designed to give parents effective ways to relate to their children, their peers and their environment.

nytimes_articles.headline:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Builder Picked For New Mall
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AFTER a year-long competition, the city planning agency has chosen a development team for a $15 million, 220,000-square-foot shopping center in Roxbury, a low-income neighborhood with high crime and few retail services.

All the retail space and 50 percent of the offices have been preleased. Fleet Bank of Massachusetts has agreed to provide construction and permanent financing. Site preparation is under way, with groundbreaking due in the fall.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANNIE'S PROMISE By Sonia Levitin. 186 pp. New York:  Atheneum. $14.95. (Ages 10 and up)

nytimes_articles.headline: Federal Inquiry Into Death of Artist in Street Fight
nytimes_articles.abstract: Federal civil-rights prosecutors in Manhattan and Washington are looking into the death of Grady Alexis, an artist killed two years ago in a Greenwich Village street fight involving an off-duty police officer.   James L. Cott, chief of the civil rights unit in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, confirmed on Friday that the incident that led to Mr. Alexis's death was under review by his office and the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department. He declined to discuss details of the case, but he said that such a review can be -- but is not necessarily -- a precursor to the filing of Federal civil-rights charges.

nytimes_articles.headline: Restoration at Glen Island
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN 1875, the 100-acre island off New Rochelle now run by the county and known as Glen Island Park was a privately owned amusement park. Now one large expanse of land, it then consisted of five islands that could only be reached by boat; each one had a different international theme. One of the most popular was set up as a German beer garden, complete with Bavarian-style stone structures built to resemble castles.   Today, two 30-foot-high stone turrets are all that remain of the old amusement park. One is used to store sculls and oars used by Iona College rowing teams; another is roped off because of the danger of falling rocks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kathleen Hansen, Kieran J. Fallon
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kathleen Marie Hansen, the daughter of Virginia L. Pavloff of Ringoes, N.J., and the late John L. Hansen, was married yesterday to Kieran John Fallon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Fallon of Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. James F. Kuntz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Peter's Church in Point Pleasant, N.J.   Mrs. Fallon, 26, is a financial analyst in the Division of Banking Supervision and Regulation at the Federal Reserve Board in Washington. She and her husband graduated summa cum laude from Georgetown University, where they were elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia University.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract:
19TH-CENTURY MUSIC

A concert today at the Old Bethpage Village Restoration on Round Swamp Road is a departure from the museum's usual approach. The Cameo Quartet, a chamber ensemble, will be at the Reception Center to perform music from around 1875, including works by Stephen Foster, Charles Ives and William Sidney Mount, plus a special arrangement of "When Johnny Comes Marching Home."

nytimes_articles.headline: Newark's Jews
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your Posting on May 30 headed "Sanctuary's Fate in the Balance" about Congregation Oheb Shalom's old sanctuary at 32 Prince Street in Newark is not entirely accurate. There are indeed other remnants of the earliest Jewish community of Newark -- among them the former Temple B'nai Jeshurun at the corner of High Street and Waverly Avenue. Actually, Congregation Oheb Shalom was an outgrowth of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pandering To Male Fantasies
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Let's face it: What every man wants (though few would admit it) is a woman capable of fulfilling his every sexual desire who will then make him a nice dinner and tuck him into bed. Since most wives and girlfriends are incapable of playing this role, or unwilling to, a man will pay to see his ideal woman flickering across the screen. Male movie executives know this and work it for all it's worth.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Seaport Salvation; Greek Revival Restoration
nytimes_articles.abstract: Frank J. Sciame couldn't help noticing 247 Water Street three years ago. That was when his firm, the F. J. Sciame Construction Company, was building the new Seamen's Church Institute, two doors to the south. At the same time, the company was looking to move out of its offices at 24 West 40th Street.   No. 247 had surely been a handsome Greek Revival structure in its day, with six trunk-like gray granite piers at its base, supporting a broad granite entablature. But decrepitude had turned into disaster in January 1990, when an entire section of brick tore off the building's facade during a snowstorm.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alisa Beth Terry And Ian Eagle
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alisa Beth Terry, the creative director for Piccoli & Piccoli, a television production company in New York, was married yesterday evening to Ian Eagle, a sports announcer at WFAN-AM radio in Astoria, Queens. Rabbi Barry Greene officiated at the Hilton at Short Hills, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Maribeth Patterson, Mark Brostowski
nytimes_articles.abstract: Maribeth Micael Patterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Patterson of Madison, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Alan Brostowski, the son of Ronald Brostowski of Taylor, Mich., and Virginia Brostowski of Dearborn Heights, Mich. The Rev. Gerard G. Schmitz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Margaret Church.   Mrs. Brostowski, 31, is the vice president of merchandising sales for Reliance Apparel, a denim manufacturer in New York. She graduated from Mary Washington College. Her father is the director of public relations for the Southern New England Telephone Company in New Haven. Her mother, Sheila M. Patterson, teaches computer skills at Daniel Hand High School in Madison.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unshackled, Unconventional Sculptor
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I THINK I did well following my nose," said the sculptor John Chamberlain. With little formal training and a resolute refusal to play by the rules the second-generation New York School artist innovated a bold development in postwar art. Thirty-six years ago Mr. Chamberlain ripped two fenders off a 1929 Ford at the home of Larry Rivers in Southampton and welded them into an abstract sculpture called "Shortstop." In so doing, he invented a method and medium for which he is well known.    His work is in the collections of institutions like the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Exhibitions attract fans from the Parrish to Paris. Mr. Chamberlain is in a position to savor success, but he continues to sniff out new challenges.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Strength for U.N. Peacekeepers: U.S. Might
nytimes_articles.abstract: In staging air and ground strikes against the militia of a Somali faction leader, United Nations forces have expanded the United Nations mandate in peacekeeping operations, while raising the issue of whether efforts by the world organization must always depend on United States firepower.   From Bosnia to Cambodia, United Nations peacekeepers fire when they are fired upon. But they do not conduct major punitive raids to neutralize stubborn foes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Playing It Close To the Head
nytimes_articles.abstract: The small round head appears to be the signature look of this summer; it's achieved with a skull cap crocheted or knitted from linen or cotton yarn in patterns that are airy and open. There is even an evening version in sparkling Lurex (above left) that young people are wearing to evening parties.    The skull cap that is sweeping the Western fashion scene is an adaptation of African and Oriental regional head coverings. The styles that cover more of the head than the originals often resemble bathing caps with the same fit that flattens the hair and drastically changes the silhouette of the head.

A reporter's gallery of heroes and villains, past and present, who made Albania, Bulgaria, Greece, Romania and the former Yugoslavia the sweethearts they are.  BODIES ELECTRIC, by Colin Harrison. (Crown, $20.) An urban thriller in which a corporate executive does a good deed and unknowingly sets perilous events in motion.  THE BUTCHER BOY, by Patrick McCabe. (Fromm International, $19.95.) A grueling and all too believable novel that enters the deranged mind of a love-starved Irish schoolboy.  CHIMNEY ROCK, by Charlie Smith. (Holt, $22.50.) Mr. Smith's novel appropriates the language and vision of Southern Gothic to the dwellers in a nasty, dusty Hollywood.  COMPULSORY HAPPINESS, by Norman Manea. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) Trevelyan (1876-1962), a Cambridge historian and Whig aristocrat, hoped to see decent liberal values established in Europe in the 20th century, but lived to see them disappear everywhere. ISLAM AND THE WEST, by Bernard Lewis. (Oxford University, $25.) THE MAN WHO WASN'T MAIGRET: A Portrait of Georges Simenon, by Patrick Marnham. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) (Pantheon, $25.) A grimly fascinating and sometimes funny account of a successful sting operation by an entertaining lot of Federal drug agents against a Colombian cocaine ring.  TINTIN IN THE NEW WORLD: A Romance, by Frederic Tuten. (Morrow, $22.) An American novelist introduces a French comic strip hero to the temptations of the real world.

nytimes_articles.headline: Janice Meagher, Gregory Trojan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Janice Coupe Meagher, a director of strategic marketing for Taco Belle, and Gregory Alan Trojan, a senior finance director for Pizza Hut, both in Irvine, Calif., were married yesterday in Rhinecliff, N.Y. The Rev. Armond Padula performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Joseph's Church.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sunshine Loyalists Perturb Sir Charles
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley is not guilt-ridden. In one season, he christened Phoenix's new arena with a conference title, gave Madonna a reason to visit town and inspired local junior high school students to shave their heads.   Cross him once, though, and he will knock a city on the seat of its pants (see Philadelphia).

nytimes_articles.headline: The Evil Empire, Continued
nytimes_articles.abstract: BLACK HUNDRED The Rise of the Extreme Right in Russia. By Walter Laqueur. Illustrated. 317 pp. New York:  HarperCollins. $27.50.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ape and Essence
nytimes_articles.abstract:
VISIONS OF CALIBAN
On Chimpanzees and People.
By Dale Peterson and
Jane Goodall.
Illustrated. 367 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Golf's 'Little Red' Twosome
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE day after Tom Kite won last year's United States Open in Pebble Beach's gusts, he had to travel to the Buick Westchester Classic. His wife, Christy, returned to their Austin, Tex., home with the shiny silver Open trophy. And with orders on what to do with it.   The next morning, she took the trophy to the Austin Country Club, where one of golf's legendary teaching pros was giving a lesson.

nytimes_articles.headline: Police Were Fewer Than Romanians Feared
nytimes_articles.abstract: For most of the last half century, Romanians lived in terror of the state intelligence service, the Securitate, under the Communist regime that held sway until the end of 1989.   It now appears that the service was much smaller than previously believed. According to a new Romanian intelligence chief, Ion Talpes, the Securitate had 16,000 full-time officers on the payroll at the time President Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown and executed in December 1989.

nytimes_articles.headline: Waiting for a Rudder at I.N.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the freighter Golden Venture ran aground off Queens last weekend, it sparked the latest crisis to confront an immigration agency that has lurched from controversy to controversy without a leader since President Clinton took office.   At a most sensitive time in immigration history, Mr. Clinton has not yet nominated an Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner or publicly articulated an immigration policy distinct from his Republican predecessor. As most senior immigration jobs are empty, the agency is being run by holdovers from the Bush Administration in Washington. And into the vacuum local I.N.S. directors, career officials like William S. Slattery in New York, have moved to reassert their power and law-enforcement priorities.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lack of Money Imperils Indian Cultural Center
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a Federal grant and a bold vision, the Native American Center for the Living Arts was designed by its founders to look like a giant turtle, its house-sized head glaring defiantly toward the brink of the American Falls several hundred yards away.   But now the Government money is gone, and the 12-year-old Turtle, as the American Indian cultural center and museum is known, is facing an increasingly uncertain future. Its debts mounted steadily until May 20, when unpaid electric bills reached $102,000 and utility workers cut off most of its power.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Deadly Sins/Anger; The Fascination Begins in the Mouth
nytimes_articles.abstract: HERE would be no point to sin if it were not the corridor to pleasure, but the corridor of anger has a particularly seductive, self-deceiving twist. More than any of the other sins, anger can be seen to be good, can perhaps even begin by being good. Jesus himself was angry, brandishing his whip and thrillingly overturning tables: coins, doves flying, the villainous sharpsters on their knees to save their spoils. It would seem to run in the family; by far the angriest character in the Old Testament is God.   Of all the sins, only anger is connected in the common tongue to its twinned, entwined virtue: justice. "Just anger," we say. Impossible even to begin to imagine such a phrase made with the others: try as you will you can't get your mouth around the words "just sloth," or "just covetousness," to say nothing of the deadly breakfast cereal that sticks to the ribs for all eternity, "just lust."

nytimes_articles.headline: Mayor's Son Gets a Scholarship, and Protest Arises
nytimes_articles.abstract: A century-old system of political patronage here has been sidetracked by public anger over Mayor Sidney Barthelemy's awarding of a Tulane University scholarship to his own son.    On Friday, Mayor Barthelemy tried to defuse the anger by announcing that his son, Sidney 2d, would not, after all, attend Tulane. And the private college in turn announced it would not honor mayoral and legislative scholarships until the rules for the patronage awards are changed.

nytimes_articles.headline:
MUSIC;
Pianist Builds a Career By Taking His Time
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE Swiss-born pianist Andreas Haefliger is one of a growing number of young musicians who have dared to say no to the competition scene and to build a career slowly and carefully, not accepting every engagement -- "the old-fashioned way," as he puts it. 

Mr. Haefliger, 30, has made a number of highly acclaimed international debuts recently, and he will give his first New Jersey performance next Sunday at 8:30 P.M. at the Cape May Music Festival. He will perform in the Congress Hall Hotel, and his program will include Sophia Gubaidulina's "Chacona," Schumann's "Davidsbundlertanze," Mozart's Sonata in F (K. 332), Debussy's "Images" Book 2 and Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz."

nytimes_articles.headline: World Cup Ticket Sale
nytimes_articles.abstract: The scramble for World Cup 1994 tickets begins anew today.   Organizers of the 52-game soccer tournament, which is being held in the United States for the first time next summer, are offering 300,000 tickets to the 44 games in the first round, when all 24 teams are competing, and the round-of-16 that follows.

nytimes_articles.headline: Page Evans, Robert Schwartz
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary Page Evans, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Beverley Evans Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Robert Crandall Schwartz, a son of Karl Schwartz 3d of Virginia Beach, Va., and the late Katherine M. Schwartz. The Rev. Dr. Adam Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Greenville, Del.    Mrs. Schwartz, 27, is known as Page. She is a master's degree candidate in liberal studies at Georgetown University. She graduated from American University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rambles in a Remote Italian Valley
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Valgrisenche is almost entirely surrounded by the Italian Alps -- mountains that have kept this verdant valley remote, preserving the culture and the French patois from the days when its rulers were French. In the most northwesterly corner of Italy, the Valgrisenche lies almost flush with the French border, a remnant of the ancient state of Savoy, an area culturally and linguistically French but held by Italy at various times from the 16th century onward. French Savoy was ceded to France by the Italian region of Piedmont in 1860. Tucked away between the celebrated Olympic ski resorts of the French Savoie such as Val d'Isere and Tignes to the west and Italy's popular Gran Paradiso national park to the east, it is often overlooked, attracting the few hikers and cross-country skiers in the winter who know its quiet old villages, profusion of Alpine wildflowers, pure air and good trails.   My husband and I drove up the Valgrisenche last July, on our way to the Gran Paradiso; the park border runs along the mountains separating the valley from the Val di Rhemes to the east. We had come to hike and decided to spend a few nights in each of the valley's three hamlets.   Our first stop was Planaval, whose old stone farmhouses, with slate roofs and wooden balconies, are tightly clustered below a waterfall-streaked cliff. Planaval is set among its fields, like a medieval village in its perfect simplicity: it consists only of a church, a few houses and one small hotel a moment's walk from the village.

nytimes_articles.headline: Variety Marks Summer Season
nytimes_articles.abstract: FRIDAY'S convergence of openings marked the end of the winter season ("Phantom" at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn) and the start of summer (the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's "Taming of the Shrew").   Besides Shakespeare, this year's festival comprises Shaw and Ibsen, and that does it for the classics of summer. For the rest, theatergoers are being offered a smattering of stars in vehicles made to measure.

nytimes_articles.headline: Emigres in New York: Work Off the Books
nytimes_articles.abstract: Leida Fermin wanted at least a modest version of the American dream. She had not left behind her family in the Dominican Republic to go on welfare or to work forever, for a pittance, in a basement tailor shop. So last year, she lugged four used sewing machines and endless yards of pink taffeta into her Manhattan apartment, creating a tiny, illegal factory to make ruffled party dresses for little girls.   "I am using my talents to support my family decently, in the only way I know how," said Ms. Fermin, 52, a legal Dominican immigrant. "It is only basic survival, really. I mean, what options do I have?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Christa Johnson, William Shaffer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Christa Farie Johnson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wyatt Thomas Johnson Jr. of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to William Leland Shaffer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leland K. Shaffer Jr. of Rockville, Md. The Rev. Dr. George Regas performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Philip.   Mrs. Shaffer, 26, was until recently a counselor at the Winter Multi-Services Center, a shelter for the homeless in Petaluma, Calif. She graduated from Southern Methodist University, where her husband received a law degree. Her father, known as Tom, is the president of the Cable News Network in Atlanta.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DANCE;
A Celebration of Nikolais-Louis Works
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A LINE of angled hands, fingers opening and closing like jaws, curls across a darkened stage like a chorus line of alligators. Almost imperceptibly, arms materialize out of the kaleidoscopically shifting light, and the hands and arms become swans, which in turn metamorphose into psychedelic giraffes. 

This is the opening of "Crucible," a 1985 choreographic venture by Alwin Nikolais that offers a reflection on evolution. (The giraffes change, amoeba-like, into a futuristic jungle of mutants, whose legs and feet are reflected in a slanted mirror.)

nytimes_articles.headline: 2-Century Tradition of Pottery In a Tiny North Carolina Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE pottery tradition of Seagrove, N.C., which stretches unbroken back to the 1750's, has flourished in the past two decades, with more than 50 potteries now operating within 20 miles of this tiny rural town. Although scores of early American potteries produced functional items from their local clay, most were displaced during the 20th century by inexpensive manufactured goods. The Seagrove potteries were an exception. Spurred by a lively wholesale trade, they hung on through the 1920's and 30's before demand declined and they dwindled to only five in the 1960's.   A revival began in the 1970's, however, fueled by a renewed market for handcrafted items. Today, some of Seagrove's potteries are owned by eighth and ninth generation artisans, others have been started by newcomers from out of state. Many operate out of weathered log cabins scattered only minutes from town.

nytimes_articles.headline: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: HUNTERS AND JUMPERS   The 64th annual Ox Ridge Horse Show will take place this week in Darien, running from Monday through Sunday at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, 512 Middlesex Road. Each day except Sunday there will be various classes of hunters and jumpers performing for ribbons and money prizes from 8 A.M. to around 5:30 P.M. Ponies and young riders will be featured on Monday and Friday, when the A.S.P.C.A. medal class competition will be held. Professional riders will have center stage on Wednesday, and equitation championships are scheduled on Saturday.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   THE review of Russ Rymer's book, "Genie: An Abused Child's Flight From Silence" (April 25), attacks the group of caretakers who worked with Genie after the girl -- who had been confined to one room for her first 13 years -- was removed from the care of her parents and hospitalized. Readers of the review may come away believing that the psychologists, linguists and social workers who cared for Genie were solely responsible for her failure to recover from her childhood abuse and for her present situation as a resident of a state institution for retarded adults. A response is warranted. This is the first time I have made any public statement on this case during the more than 22 years that have elapsed since it first came to light.

nytimes_articles.headline: MAYOR AND COUNCIL MAKE BUDGET PACT FOR NEW YORK CITY
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mayor David N. Dinkins and the New York City Council agreed early yesterday morning on a $31.2 billion budget that holds taxes steady, clips some social programs but still grows by nearly $1.8 billion over last year's adopted budget.   The Council's leaders and the administration reached an accord at 4:30 yesterday morning, resolving a week of tense and at times acrimonious negotiations over the shape of nearly $300 million in spending cuts by agreeing not to cut services quite so deeply as the Mayor had initially proposed.

nytimes_articles.headline:
GOLF;
Surprising Lidback Leads L.P.G.A.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The pressure of major tournament golf is usually too much for inexperienced players, but it doesn't seem to be bothering Jenny Lidback this week at the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship.

While a host of more experienced players buckled under the strain brought on by exacting course conditions, a $1 million purse and the instant fame accorded to leaders in a major championship, the unheralded and nonexempt Lidback was nearly flawless. She shot a three-under-par 68 today at Bethesda Country Club to take a two-shot lead after three rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association's most important tournament.

nytimes_articles.headline: From Fifis To Tutus
nytimes_articles.abstract: A newly reopened museum, a bridal couple, aspiring dancers, flowering trees, and at the Fifi Awards, some glorious fragrances.

nytimes_articles.headline: These Mets May Be Old, But They Can Still Win
nytimes_articles.abstract: Reggie Jackson didn't come. Neither did Catfish Hunter or Tom Seaver or Willie Mays. The crowd at Shea Stadium was sparse, and the Oakland A's roster was so short that the A's needed to use a player -- Bill North -- who had not even been on their 1973 World Series team.   None of that mattered, though, to the 1973 New York Mets. Yesterday, those Mets managed to do what they couldn't in Game 7 of the 1973 World Series -- they beat the Oakland A's.

nytimes_articles.headline: Postal Service Can't Stop Rocking
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR rock-and-roll collectors or those not sated by the half-billion Elvis Presley stamps distributed this year, the United States Postal Service is issuing seven stamps on Wednesday featuring Elvis (yes, again) and six other paragons of pop.    (Country fans take note: Last Wednesday the Postal Service issued a 29-cent stamp featuring Hank Williams.)

nytimes_articles.headline: Even the Other Nazis Didn't Like Him
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RIBBENTROP
By Michael Bloch.
Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: 
Crown Publishers.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RELIGIOUS THOUGHT
ASSIMILATION VERSUS SEPARATION
Joseph the Administrator and the Politics of Religion in Biblical Israel.
By Aaron Wildavsky.
Transaction/Rutgers University, $32.95.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: Ardsley;
And the High School Band Played On
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JOE GRECCO, former band leader at the high school here, wasn't mincing words. "This is the best moment of my life," he said. Nor were the people who had been his students from 1958 through 1973 holding back emotions. Punctuating the strains of brass, woodwinds and percussion were throat clearings and coughs and a few outright sniffles. 

When Mr. Grecco, a trim and lively 59-year-old, said, "I defy any group of musicians to do what you've done here tonight," the band members responded with loud applause and calls of "it's because of you, Joe."

nytimes_articles.headline:
OUT THERE: WASHINGTON;
It's Clinton's Kind of Place
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AN elderly gentleman wearing a green plaid jacket and purple tie sat at the Florida Avenue Grill's counter, across from glossies of Sugar Ray Leonard and a youthful Jesse Jackson, and surrounded by a crush of jump-suited construction workers. The scent of greens with ham, fried apples and scrapple was breathtaking. A waitress asked, "What you having, baby?" The man said, "Lunch."

"Chitterlings is fresh."

nytimes_articles.headline: Citibank Starts New Flier Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Citibank has introduced a program in which its Visa and Mastercard customers can obtain frequent-flier points by charging purchases on their credit cards.    It replaces a similar program, operated by an outside concern, called Air Miles, which has been suspended in the United States.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: The picture caption on the cover of the Television section today misstates the time for "Brides of Christ," a three-part mini-series tonight on Arts & Entertainment. It begins at 8.

nytimes_articles.headline: English Tourism
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Having made a week's visit to London earlier this year, my wife and I were interested in William E. Schmidt's report in the Travel Advisory ("Consumer Group Says Stonehenge Is a 'Disgrace,,' " March 21) about conditions at Stonehenge and the Tower of London.   While time did not permit us a visit to Stonehenge, we did spend an informative and enjoyable morning at the Tower of London. This was due in large part to our yeoman warder guide who deftly mixed facts and morbid humor in his recitation of the tower's grisly history. In terms of the crown jewels, what was upsetting was not the "cattle-pen queueing system" (familiar after all to veterans of Disney World and Universal Studios) but being rudely herded past the jewels once you got inside. Surly guards continually muttered "No stopping," "Keep it moving," and even "No staring."

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; Ways and Means
nytimes_articles.abstract: With jurisdiction over taxes, trade law, health and welfare, the House Ways and Means Committee wields tremendous power. The chairman's job is tough and time-consuming. But for Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the position is not without its rewards.    A story in Congressional Quarterly reveals Mr. Rostenkowski as a master -- perhaps the master -- of the Congressional art of princely living. The account, written by Phil Kuntz, spotlights two scandals that are central to the current battle over political reform: the use of campaign war chests as personal slush funds, and the lobbyist-provided perks that guarantee Mr. Rostenkowski and many of his colleagues a life of blissful bondage.

nytimes_articles.headline: Help for Compulsive Spenders
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SOME breeze through a department store in a trance, making purchases right and left, unaware of what they have bought. Others flip on the television to a home shopping channel in the dead of night and call in to buy the trinkets and housewares blinking at them from the screen. Still others order item after item from the glossy pages of mail-order catalogues. 

Whatever the method, the problem is the same: compulsive spending, or debting, as the experts call it. Though the easy availability of credit cards and the proliferation of shopping malls and televised shopping may play a role, the underlying cause, they say, is the same as for disorders like overeating or compulsive gambling -- low self-esteem. And like these ailments, compulsive spending has spawned specialists and treatment programs in the state.

nytimes_articles.headline: Richard Price On the Addictions Of Hollywood
nytimes_articles.abstract: Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, once described Richard Price as "a novelist whose work was cinematic long before it ever reached the screen."   "Beginning with 'The Wanderers' in 1979, and most recently with last year's 'Clockers,' " she went on, "he has written about tough urban situations in vibrant, colorful language the reader can truly see and hear."

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Poppies Grow
nytimes_articles.abstract: A HOUSE IN FLANDERS By Michael Jenkins. Illustrated by Catherine Jenkins. 159 pp. New York: Viking.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Do Clothes Mean To an Artist Anyway?
nytimes_articles.abstract: "FALL FROM FASHION" at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield is not about fashion, at least not in the haute couture or Seventh Avenue sense of the term. It is rather a comment on clothing and its significance, as perceived by artists. The show, which was organized by the museum's director, Barry A. Rosenberg, comes with a glossy catalogue. Unfortunately, too many of its pages are virtually empty and, as if to compensate, the layout is dreadfully tricky.    What is more, the silver cover aims to be provocative by featuring a photograph of a bearded, ponytailed young man in a dowdy dress, along with the question "Are Today's Artists Hung Up on Clothing?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Play About Art Fosters Art
nytimes_articles.abstract: ART is begetting art, or so it seems, at the Schoolhouse, a theater space and gallery, where oil paintings by Michael Patterson in an exhibition titled "Conversations/Villages/Open Spaces" is on through July 4.   The show provides a fitting segue to the play, or is it the other way around? "Sight Unseen" by Donald Margulies is about the purpose of art -- and a lot more -- but how many plays concern themselves with contemporary painters in the first place?

nytimes_articles.headline: Loroupe Leads Rarely Tardy Kenyans
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tecla Loroupe's vivid memories of her Kenyan school days served her well in New York. Like a schoolgirl who knows exactly what's in store if she's late for the opening bell, the 20-year-old Kenyan fairly flew through Central Park yesterday to get to the finish on time to win the 22d annual Advil Mini Marathon.   Behind her were a score of elite runners straining for success and some 5,500 other women, many of whom couldn't have cared less about the dramatic duels at the head of the chase or even about their own times in the 10-kilometer race. Schuwalow Finishes Strong    For those who did care, however, the victory could hardly have been more impressive. Loroupe, who ran stride for graceful stride with Lisa Ondieki of Australia before breaking away between the fourth and fifth miles, covered the hilly 6.2-mile course in 32 minutes 31 seconds, 18 seconds ahead of Carolyn Schuwalow of Australia, who surged ahead of a tiring Ondieki in the last few hundred yards.

nytimes_articles.headline: Effort to Bar Plea Deals Is Under Fire
nytimes_articles.abstract: In November District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx announced what appeared to be a brash attack on the status quo: no longer would he offer plea bargains to indicted felony suspects, no matter the cost to the court system.   Now, after nearly seven months, the granite walls of the Bronx County Courthouse have not tumbled down as many had feared. Yet Mr. Johnson's unorthodox approach has begun to strain the criminal justice system.

nytimes_articles.headline: Azerbaijan Says Armenians Are Gaining Ground in Heavy Fighting
nytimes_articles.abstract: Armenian forces from the disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh in Azerbaijan attacked the western city of Agdam early today, military and civilian officials there said.   The officials said the attack occurred hours after a midnight deadline expired for the local Armenians to agree to a proposed timetable for a cease-fire. The Armenian forces were reported to have captured several villages, and fighting was reported throughout the day. No casualty figures were available.

nytimes_articles.headline: Linda Brockelman and W. S. Ogden Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Linda Maughan Brockelman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anton H. Brockelman Jr. of Simsbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to William S. Ogden Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Robert Naylor performed the Congregational ceremony at the First Church of Christ.   Mrs. Ogden, 31, is due to become an institutional securities trader next month at Alex Brown & Company, a securities brokerage in Baltimore. The bride graduated from Williams College. She and her husband received M.B.A. degrees from the University of Virginia.

nytimes_articles.headline: E. C. McPherson, J. B. Trevor 4th
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eugenie Chester McPherson, the daughter of Mrs. Gregory A. Sharp of Northford, Conn., and Stephen M. McPherson of New York, was married yesterday to John Bond Trevor 4th, the son of Mrs. Eugene Quinn of Washington and Mr. Trevor 3d of Lake Placid, N.Y. The Rev. David Ames performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y.   The bride, 27, is the assistant to the executive director of Planned Parenthood of Rhode Island in Providence. She and her husband graduated from the University of Colorado. Her father is a managing director of Ward Howell International Inc., an executive search concern in New York. Her mother, Penelope Sharp, is an environmental consultant in Northford.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Region: Westchester; First-Timers Find a Co-op's the Best Bet
nytimes_articles.abstract: LAST YEAR, when Judy Rubinstein decided to move to lower Westchester County, she didn't think she would wind up in a co-op.   "I was opposed to co-ops," she said. But after looking at about a dozen, she bought a one-bedroom in Yonkers.

nytimes_articles.headline: At 50, Conner Wary of Whitbread
nytimes_articles.abstract: The usually confident and often cocky Dennis Conner turns hesitant when it comes to a discussion about sailing in the Whitbread Round the World Race. This attitudinal quirk has nothing to do with his team's ability to win, but rather, whether Conner wants to sail with his team.   "I have some trepidation about it, honestly," the 50-year-old Conner said in an interview last week. "This is a young man's deal. When you get down to the Roaring Forties, you're cold and wet, and there are no showers. There is no way to get away."

nytimes_articles.headline: All the Color Was on the Canvas
nytimes_articles.abstract: JUAN GRIS By Christopher Green with contributions by Christian Derouet and Karin von Maur. Illustrated. 311 pp. New Haven:  Whitechapel Art Gallery/ Yale University Press. $50.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Connecticut Q&A;: Michael B. Jones;
A Few Simple Rules for Biking Safety
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN Michael B. Jones began to talk to other Weston residents about bicycle safety, he heard four remarkable stories in just one week. One child, not wearing a helmet, rode his bike directly into the path of an oncoming car, flew right over it and somehow was unhurt. Another, whose mother allowed him to ride down the street on his tricycle without a helmet once, flipped over and had to have stitches in his forehead. And a third, an adolescent not in the habit of wearing a helmet, but doing so, lost control of her bike and smashed into a tree; the helmet was destroyed, but she was fine.

Those stories and a host of attention-grabbing statistics are among the tools Mr. Jones employs in his crusade for safe cycling. With the AAA club in Connecticut and several other sponsors, Mr. Jones recently held a statewide conference on safe cycling at the Waterbury Sheraton. The conference's objective: to put the issue on the legislative agenda and to get the attention of the insurance industry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Janzen and Waldorf Are 1 and 1A in the Buick
nytimes_articles.abstract: With bogeys remaining far more prevalent than birdies, Lee Janzen and Duffy Waldorf shared a three-stroke lead today after the third round of the Buick Classic.   The two were tied at four-under-par 209 over what has been a rugged Westchester Country Club course. Only two other players were under par after 54 holes, Ian Baker-Finch and Lorne Roberts, both at one-under 212.

nytimes_articles.headline: JERSEYANA
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ON July 6, 1863 (130 years ago next month), Capt. Henry Sawyer of the Army of the Potomac sat down to write a letter to his wife back in New Jersey. "My Dear Wife," he began, "I am under the necessity of informing you that my prospect looks dark." He wasn't kidding.

Sawyer was a carpenter in Cape May when Fort Sumter was fired upon in April 1861. He was one of the first New Jerseyans to volunteer to defend the Union, and within a year and a half he rose from a private in the infantry to captain in the First New Jersey Cavalry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gutter Replacement: Project for Two People
nytimes_articles.abstract: REPLACING worn-out aluminum or galvanized gutters with vinyl ones is usually a relatively easy job for two people. Generally, the main criterion is easy access to the roof.   Vinyl gutters cost about the same as aluminum but are easier to join, require no maintenance other than cleaning and are sturdy enough to resist denting from a ladder leaning against them.

nytimes_articles.headline: Julie Ann Oehler, Arthur Judson 3d
nytimes_articles.abstract: Julie Ann Oehler, the daughter of Kenneth C. Oehler of Chicago and the late Carole S. Oehler, was married yesterday to Arthur Judson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Judson 2d of Philadelphia. The Rev. Richard C. Weymouth performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel of the Salisbury (Conn.) School, a private academy.   Mrs. Judson, 25, is an assistant retail manager in Philadelphia for Rodier-Paris, a women's clothing boutique. She graduated from the University of North Carolina. Her father is the director of human resources at Unitrin Insurance in Chicago. Her mother was a coordinator of the children's arts programs at the Art Institute of Chicago.

nytimes_articles.headline: NOTES
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It comes full circle," Ginger Rogers said at a party last weekend for the Los Angeles premiere of "Crazy for You." In 1985, the actress directed the two leads in the production, Karen Ziemba and James Brennan, in "Babes in Arms."   She pointed out that "a lot of people don't remember that I originated the role on Broadway." In 1930, she played the ingenue in "Girl Crazy," from which many of the "Crazy for You" songs were taken.

nytimes_articles.headline: Microsoft and 2 Cable Giants Close to an Alliance
nytimes_articles.abstract: Three dominant technology and entertainment companies are on the verge of joining forces to create the equivalent of software for cable television -- an operating system that would combine the worlds of computing and television and perhaps shape how much of popular culture is delivered.   Time Warner Inc., the largest entertainment company; Tele-Communications Inc., the largest cable television company, and the Microsoft Corporation, the largest software company, are expected to announce by the end of the month that they will form a company, tentatively called Cablesoft. This new venture, its creators hope, will lead the way in establishing a standard for the transmission of the coming generation of interactive programs.

nytimes_articles.headline: FILM
nytimes_articles.abstract: June    "LAST ACTION HERO." Arnold Schwarzenegger spoofs his image in one of the summer's biggest movies, the one that tied up traffic in Times Square this spring. An 11-year-old boy lands inside a movie starring his larger-than-life hero, Jack Slater (guess who?). Expect to see more of the recent, less violent Arnold, true to those kinder, gentler values he picked up during the Bush era. Directed by John McTiernan ("Die Hard"). Opens June 18.   "SLEEPLESS IN SEATTLE." Tom Hanks is a widower who lives in Seattle with his young son. Meg Ryan is a Baltimore journalist who falls in love when she hears them on a radio call-in show. Directed by Nora Ephron (who wrote "When Harry Met Sally"), this willfully sentimental movie is expected to sew up the romantic-comedy business for the summer. Opens June 25.    "THE FIRM." Tom Cruise stars as an ambitious Ivy League lawyer who innocently lands in a Memphis firm that fronts for the Mafia (so how smart can he be?) in this thriller based on John Grisham's best-selling novel. Directed by the unbeatable Sydney Pollack ("Tootsie" and "Out of Africa," so let's forget about "Havana"). Opens June 30.July    "SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS." Someday her video will come, but for now here's the re-release of the 1937 original. Opens July 2.   "IN THE LINE OF FIRE." Clint Eastwood stars as a Secret Service agent who couldn't save J. F. K. Now he's out to save the current President from a mad killer (John Malkovich) and determined to create a new tag line from the movie, "That's not gonna happen." (Say it with a snarl.) Directed by Wolfgang Petersen ("Das Boot"). Opens July 9.   "FREE WILLY." Good advance word (if you consider making grown-ups cry a good sign) on this story of an orphaned boy named Jesse and the orca whale named Willy he tries to free. The Hollywood buzz is calling this the big family film of the summer. Opens July 16.   "AMONGST FRIENDS." This first film by Rob Weiss won raves as a "Mean Streets Jr." at the Sundance Film Festival. Five friends from a wealthy Jewish and Italian section of Long Island become involved with the mob. Opens July 23.    "CONEHEADS." Straight from the planet Remulac, via the old days of "Saturday Night Live," the Conehead family (Dan Aykroyd, Jane Curtin, and Michelle Burke as their teen-age daughter, Connie) make a life for themselves in Paramus, N.J. Opens July 23.    "POETIC JUSTICE." Before Bill Clinton signed up Maya Angelou as the Inaugural poet, John Singleton (writer and director of "Boyz N the Hood") signed her up to write poems for his ambitious, offbeat second film. Janet Jackson stars as a reclusive poet and hairdresser named Justice who falls in love with a postal worker (Tupac Shakur). Opens July 23.   "RISING SUN." Sean Connery is the only Los Angeles detective who understands the Japanese character, and Wesley Snipes is the partner he leads through a murder investigation involving a powerful Japanese corporation. If you've read the Michael Crichton novel (the one he hates to hear called a Japan-bashing book), be prepared for a change: same murder, different murderer. Directed by Philip Kaufman ("The Right Stuff"). Opens July 30.   "ROBIN HOOD: MEN IN TIGHTS." Mel Brooks spoofs the Robin Hood legend and tries to do for swashbucklers what he did for westerns in "Blazing Saddles" and monster movies in "Young Frankenstein." Opens July 30.   August    "THE FUGITIVE." In this remake of the television series, Harrison Ford stars as Dr. Richard Kimble, falsely accused of murdering his wife, on the lam and searching for the one-armed man. Opens Aug. 6.   "HEART AND SOULS." This is described as a fantasy-comedy, and considering the plot, thank goodness. After Charles Grodin, Alfre Woodard, Kyra Sedgwick and David Paymer are killed in a bus accident, their spirits attach themselves to a newborn baby, who growns up to be Robert Downey Jr. Directed by Ron Underwood ("City Slickers"). Opens Aug. 6.   "THE MAN WITHOUT A FACE." The first film directed by Mel Gibson. He stars as an outcast man with a badly scarred face (that's one way to change an image), who befriends an unhappy 12-year-old boy. Opens Aug. 20.   "MANHATTAN MURDER MYSTERY." This is the film Woody Allen was directing last summer when the story of his messy personal life exploded in the tabloids. Diane Keaton replaced Mia Farrow and Anjelica Huston replaced a much younger actress as Mr. Allen's on-screen love interest. The title explains the plot, but the real mystery is how moviegoers will react to the post-scandal Woody. Opens Aug. 20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mediators Fly to Croatia To Broach Peace Options
nytimes_articles.abstract: Thwarted by continued fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the threat of a new war in Croatia, international mediators unexpectedly flew to Zagreb today to discuss possible changes in their troubled peace plan with President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, officials familiar with the initiative said.   Although they refused to discuss the proposed changes in any detail, those officials said the mediators, Lord Owen and Thorvald Stoltenberg, were reviewing their plan for dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina into 10 largely autonomous provinces under a weak central government and considering changes that might effectively partition the country into separate regions of Serbs, Croats and Muslims instead.

nytimes_articles.headline: She Needs Boys
nytimes_articles.abstract:
EKATERINA
By Donald Harington.
373 pp. New York:
Harcourt Brace & Company.

nytimes_articles.headline: Favorite for High Court Failed to Pay Maid's Taxes
nytimes_articles.abstract: White House officials confirmed this evening that President Clinton's leading choice for the Supreme Court had not paid Social Security taxes on the wages of a part-time housekeeper.   But the officials said the disclosure about Judge Stephen G. Breyer had nothing to do with Mr. Clinton's decision earlier today to put off, until at least Monday, his announcement of a Supreme Court nominee.

nytimes_articles.headline: New York Acts On Rental Cars
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York is following Florida and Colorado in removing any identifying designations from the license plates of rental cars.   Auto rental companies were among those calling for a change after a German tourist driving a rented car was killed in Miami in April. The companies say marked cars have been a target for years, although a spokesman for Hertz, Joseph Russo, hastened to say that "the problem seen in Florida has not occurred elsewhere, except in terms of auto theft."

nytimes_articles.headline: Tight-Money Tactics of Depression Era Return
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "The Federal Reserve Prepares for a Rate War" (Business Day, June 1) reports that the Federal Open Market Committee on May 18 gave Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Chairman, "leeway to raise short-term interest rates, now 3 percent, by up to one-half of 1 percent before the next meeting in early July."    If this information, leaked from the supposedly secret meeting of the Federal Reserve's main policy-making committee, proves correct, it strongly indicates the Fed's policies of tight money will continue at the peril of the United States economy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Golf Tourney and Strike Carry On at Country Club
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the Buick Classic golf tournament entered its fifth day at Westchester Country Club here, opinions differed sharply over the effect of a 10-month-old strike by 65 of the club's waiters, bartenders, cooks, busboys and dishwashers.   Thomas A. Williams, chairman of the Classic and of United Hospital Medical Center in Portchester, which sponsors the event, said that the presence of picketing workers had not altered the tournament's atmosphere. "Everything is on course," he said. "We're drawing just as many spectators as usual. The strike hasn't affected the mood. It's not an issue that seems to be on people's minds." 'No Disruptions'    Robert C. James, executive director of Westchester Country Club, said, "The tournament has gone on as planned, with no disruptions."

nytimes_articles.headline: 'The Blab of the Pave'
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE CITY IN SLANG
New York Life and Popular Speech.
By Irving Lewis Allen.
Illustrated. 307 pp. New York: 
Oxford University Press. $25.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elizabeth Brack, Mark E. Mullen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Mulveyhill Brack, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Kufeld Brack Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Edward Mullen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Mullen of New Orleans. The Rev. Sandra Stayner performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.    Mrs. Mullen, 27, is a freelance television-news and magazine reporter in San Francisco. She graduated from Vanderbilt University. Her father is the chairman and chief executive of Time Inc. in New York, the magazine publishing division of Time Warner Inc., and the chairman of the National Urban League.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Roberts, Mr. Schneiderhan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Martha Landon Roberts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Roberts Jr. of Elmira, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John William Schneiderhan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Schneiderhan of Harwich , Mass. The Rev. Richard Kuenkler performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.   Mrs. Schneiderhan, 28, is the manager of the Rand McNally Map and Travel Store in Short Hills, N.J. She graduated from the University of Hartford. Her father is the vice president of the Hilliard Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial products in Elmira. Her mother, Mary B. Roberts, is the director of development for Planned Parenthood of the Southern Tier there.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chicago Takes Phoenix Right to Grand Canyon
nytimes_articles.abstract: Reflecting on the Chicago Bulls' latest victory, Coach Phil Jackson said, "At some point in the game, I didn't think there was any way we were going to lose, regardless of what happened."   That statement typifies the Bulls' attitude throughout the playoffs. They have the confidence of a championship team, and the talent and experience to go with it. And by defeating the Phoenix Suns, 111-108, in Game 2 of the National Basketball Association championship series, the Bulls continued their impressive march toward what seems to be an inevitable third straight title.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unhappy Warriors
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE PUGILIST AT REST Stories. By Thom Jones. 230 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $18.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mary Beth Jordan And Don Morris
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary Beth Jordan, the deputy editor of Child magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Don Morris, a graphic designer, also in New York. The Rev. John Quinn performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Chapel of the Divine Compassion at the Good Counsel Convent in White Plains.   Ms. Jordan is keeping her name. She graduated from Brown University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Jordan Jr. of White Plains. Her father is the chairman of Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor Inc., an advertising agency in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Europeans Fear Unemployment Will Only Rise
nytimes_articles.abstract: A new unease has taken hold in Western Europe as the conviction grows that record levels of unemployment may be tied less to the region's economic slump than to fundamental shifts in the work place and in the global economy that will persist beyond the current recession.   Last year, as the number of jobless mounted, the focus was on high German interest rates. By discouraging investment and consumption, the argument went, the high cost of money in Western Europe was delaying recovery and the creation of jobs. But as the rates have fallen this year, without any immediate response, awareness has grown that something deeper may be wrong.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bayport  $135,000  319 Fairview Avenue  3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, den, finished basement, fireplace; taxes $5,700. Bohemia  $155,000   423 8th Street  4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; dining room, new eat-in kitchen, basement, skylights, oak floors, 1-car attached garage; taxes $4,200. Levittown  $133,000   64 Honeysuckle Road  4-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, 1-car detached garage, 60- by 100-foot lot; taxes $3,600. Moriches  $155,000   594 Moriches Middle Road  4-bedroom, 3-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, deck, inground pool; taxes $4,500. Ronkonkoma  $119,000   33 Ozark Street  2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, attic; taxes $2,500. Sayville  $146,000   394 Wyandanch Road  3-bedroom, 1 1/22-bath, 29-year-old ranch; dining room, den, basement; taxes $4,500.
