nytimes_articles.headline: Gun Laws: Mood Change in the Northeast
nytimes_articles.abstract: On consecutive nights this week in Hartford and Albany, you could see the once-immovable politics of gun control shifting like tectonic plates.   Votes taken in both capitals to ban assault weapons suggested that politicians, at least in the crime-weary Northeast, sense movement in popular opinion about the always delicate relationship between the demand for public safety and the right to bear arms.

nytimes_articles.headline: Welfare Mothers Have a Big Job to Do Raising Their Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Clinton Idea Used to Limit Welfare" (news article, June 2) reports on the dilemma of the Clinton Administration on welfare reform.    You report that states are beginning to create regulations under which women will lose benefits after two years as recipients of Aid to Dependent Children, but without the day care, training and supportive services specified by President Clinton (and David T. Ellwood, his nominee for Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for planning and evaluation) as a condition for "ending welfare as we know it."

nytimes_articles.headline: At Garden State Park, A Battle for Survival
nytimes_articles.abstract:
GARDEN STATE PARK, with half-a-century of a thoroughbred racing tradition, is in a race for its own survival. The six-month thoroughbred season that ended on May 29 may be its last. The track, which opened in 1942, will be sold by Dec. 4 to the highest bidder -- whether that buyer intends to continue racing or tear down the track for other commercial development. 

During its heyday, the country's best horses -- including Citation, Secretariat and Bold Ruler -- regularly raced at Garden State, often before crowds that exceeded 40,000 fans a day. This year the track drew fewer than 40,000 people a week.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
A Gallery Makes Its Debut
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ART doesn't have a permanent zip code," Joseph Szoecs declares. He explains that art used to be centered in Rome, then Paris and later New York, so why not Jersey City? Mr. Szoecs has a five-year lease on a former machine shop he recently converted into the Trans Hudson Gallery, and he says that making Jersey City synonymous with the best in contemporary art is his goal.

 To carry out his vision, he has mounted as his first show a large and varied group exhibition called "Fusion." The title furthers what the gallery's name portends, that he is taking art from both sides of the river. The show is two-thirds New Jersey and one-third New York City, but precise numbers are not the point. Mr. Szoecs (pronounced search) notes that his artists come from many places -- Hungary, Sweden and California, for example -- and happen to live on either bank of the Hudson. (Mr. Szoecs himself is originally from Hungary.)

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: FICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: SUSPENSE A PHILOSOPHICAL INVESTIGATION By Philip Kerr. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hiking Britain, From End to End
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SOME years ago, while on vacation in southwest Cornwall, a friend and I became aware of the extensive array of excellent long-distance footpaths dispersed over much of Britain. I also learned that walking from one end of the country to the other was a challenge met by some Britons in one uninterrupted ramble of perhaps three months' duration. Two years later, in 1986, my friend, Patricia, and I -- a couple of physically unexceptional, middle-aged Americans -- began a more prolonged version of this walk: a six-year, 1,400-mile hike from the southwest corner of England at Land's End to the northeast corner of Scotland at John O'Groats. 

We did not spend 72 consecutive months walking up Britain; we walked only during our vacations, usually three weeks in May or June. But we enjoyed a continued engagement with our adventure between each hike as we pored over photos and notes and scrutinized maps and guidebooks in preparation for our next trek.

nytimes_articles.headline: BENEFITS
nytimes_articles.abstract: For Inwood House   MONDAY -- A dinner-dance will benefit Inwood House, a counseling and housing program for pregnant teen-agers in New York. A 7 P.M. cocktail party at the Puck Building, Lafayette and Houston Streets, will be followed by a sit-down dinner at 8 and a buffet supper at 9. Carrie Mae Weems, a photographer, will be honored; B. J. Crosby, a gospel and jazz singer, will perform, and Dave Brown and the Versatiles will provide the music for dancing. Tickets, $300, or $125 for the buffet and dance alone, from (212) 355-6363.

nytimes_articles.headline: Some Tough Guys Who Also Sew Nicely
nytimes_articles.abstract:
EARLY in the day, in a room with a view of picnic tables and coils of barbed wire, 22 men in jeans and sweatshirts stood listening to a woman in a blue apron tell them about crack babies and babies with AIDS and about how to make quilts to give to these babies.

Two hours later, the men were laughing and talking as they waited their turn at six sewing machines. Twenty-two quilts, with prints of teddy bears or clowns or animals, were taking shape at the Enfield Correctional Institution, and by late afternoon they would be finished.

nytimes_articles.headline: As Bosnia War Rages, General Warns of U.N. Pullout
nytimes_articles.abstract: As fighting raged across the country and relief convoys came under heavy fire, the top United Nations general in Bosnia and Herzegovina warned today that the United Nations would "have no option but to withdraw" its forces unless leaders of Serbs, Croats and Muslims expressed support for peace.   The commander, Gen. Philippe Morillon of France, said fighting had intensified in central Bosnia and around the towns of Maglaj, Doboj and Brcko in complete disregard of cease-fire accords reached in April and May.

nytimes_articles.headline: Monica Feinberg, Jeffrey Cohen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Monica Lesley Feinberg and Jeffrey Charles Cohen, doctoral students at Columbia University, she in English literature and he in philosophy, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Paul Steinberg performed the ceremony at Temple Rodeph Sholom.   The bride, 28, graduated summa cum laude from Yale University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey B. Feinberg of New York. Her father is a psychiatrist.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Vows Full Review of U.S. Role in Salvador
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to criticism by lawmakers that American officials condoned massacres by the Salvadoran Army and death-squad killings in the 1980's, President Clinton has promised Congress his Administration will make a full review of United States involvement in El Salvador.   Mr. Clinton's decision, announced in a June 7 letter to several Democratic Congressional leaders, comes more than two months after a report sponsored by the United Nations detailed extensive human rights violations committed by Salvadoran military officers whose careers benefited from American support.

nytimes_articles.headline: Laura Thornton, David Pellegrino
nytimes_articles.abstract: Laura McNiece Thornton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Thornton of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Guy Pellegrino, a son of Pamela B. Pellegrino of Fort Salonga, L.I., and Louis A. Pellegrino of Patchogue, L.I. The Rev. Donald J. Desmond performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Most Holy Trinity in Easthampton, L.I.   Ms. Thornton, 26, is keeping her name. She is the financial-operations coordinator for the Women's Tennis Council, the governing body of the Kraft women's professional tour, in New York. She graduated from Colby College.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 2d Generation Visits Fresh Air Camp
nytimes_articles.abstract: For Raheem Bowman, a 10-year-old from Manhattan, the Fresh Air Fund camping program is a family tradition. His mother, Marie Bowman, was a Fresh Air Fund camper more than 30 years ago.    Seeing the excitement in Raheem's face during a tour of Camp Hidden Valley in Fishkill, N.Y., brought back memories of great summers for Ms. Bowman. "It's good to know that they are still running such good programs," she said.

nytimes_articles.headline: An Exuberant Epson: No Simple Deals
nytimes_articles.abstract: IF you play a large number of bridge deals, what percentage would you expect to consist of slam contracts? Game contracts? Part-score contracts? Based on an analysis of 224 deals in the 1957 world championship, the answer is 10-48-42. This indicates that in a normal session of play one can expect two or three slams, with games slightly outnumbering part scores for the rest of the deals.    If a session is particularly exciting, the slam percentage will go up and the part-score percentage down. In this respect the deals in the first session of the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest eight days ago were off the scale: 26-70-4. The second session was also skewed, but less so: 10-75-15. (Only the first 24 deals, played by all contestants, are taken into account, and 5 deals likely to end in doubled part-score contracts have been ignored.)

nytimes_articles.headline: Rachel Vail, Mitchell Elkind
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rachel Vail, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey T. Vail of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Mitchell S. Elkind, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Elkind, also of New Rochelle. Rabbi Miriam Ancis officiated at the Harvard Club in New York.   Mrs. Elkind, 26, is an author whose novels "Wonder" and "Do-Over" were published by Orchard Books. She graduated from Georgetown University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Second Generations Try to Heal Wounds From World War II
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FOR many years Alan Berkowitz did not know about his father's life in the forest. Mr. Berkowitz, 33, a West Hartford resident, said that when he was growing up, he tried to find out how his father, who died when Mr. Berkowitz was 10, had survived the Holocaust. But whenever he questioned his grandmother, the soft-spoken woman would say in a firm voice, "The war is over." 

Mr. Berkowitz began to piece together his father's past on a trip to Israel during college when he met a cousin who explained how Mr. Berkowitz's father, at the age of 12, had escaped with his parents into the woods in December of 1942, two days before the Nazis murdered the Jewish people in their town or transported them to concentration camps. The family lived in the forest with partisans until the area was liberated about two year later.

nytimes_articles.headline: Facing the Problem Of County Gangs
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE jagged scar begins three inches above Luis Cruz's left ear, clearly visible through his closely cropped haircut, and continues down to the middle of his neck. "It's a long story," the 21-year-old said. "We were young and thickheaded then."   It started with a squabble at school over a girl, continued with retaliatory skirmishes between two rival youth groups and exploded one night two years ago on a street corner on this city's west side, a crowded jumble of housing projects, apartment buildings and modest one- and two-family houses.

nytimes_articles.headline: Susanna Porter, James Clark Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susanna Lansing Porter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoy H. Porter of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was married yesterday in Sag Harbor, L.I., to James Mott Clark Jr., the son of Mrs. Clark of Baltimore and the late Mr. Clark. The Rev. Christine B. Rannie Grimbol, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of Cheryl Merser and Michael Shnayerson, friends of the couple.

nytimes_articles.headline: MUSIC: Pianist Builds a Career By Taking His Time
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE Swiss-born pianist Andreas Haefliger is one of a growing number of young musicians who have dared to say no to the competition scene and to build a career slowly and carefully, not accepting every engagement -- "the old-fashioned way," as he puts it.

 Mr. Haefliger, 30, has made a number of highly acclaimed international debuts recently, and he will give his first New Jersey performance next Sunday at 8:30 P.M. at the Cape May Music Festival. He will perform in the Congress Hall Hotel, and his program will include Sophia Gubaidulina's "Chacona," Schumann's "Davidsbundlertanze," Mozart's Sonata in F (K. 332), Debussy's "Images" Book 2 and Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz."

nytimes_articles.headline: Storybook Saga Ends
nytimes_articles.abstract: A team of lawyers, doctors, machinists and factory workers just missed pulling off one of the biggest upsets in soccer history yesterday, playing a team of highly paid professionals even for 77 minutes before losing, 1-0, in the final of the German Cup.   ULF KIRSTEN's second-half goal off the chest of Hertha goalie CHRISTIAN ZIEGLER powered Bayer Leverkusen past the Hertha BSC Amateurs, 1-0, in the Cup finals, ending the saga of one of the biggest underdogs in the game's history. Hertha BSC was the first amateur team ever to reach the finals in the 50 years of the German Football Association playoffs. Hundreds of professional and amateur teams in the country compete to win the cup.

nytimes_articles.headline: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
nytimes_articles.abstract: Agents of the Law   WHEN Pat Ricioppo heard the leaves rustling, she knew it wasn't just another day in her hometown of Lynbrook. "I looked up," she said, "and I couldn't believe it. There were two strange-looking men in a tree. I thought they were homeless people."   Actually they were marines, in sniper camouflage. "We're on display today," said a green-faced Anthony McDonough of Islip, who on terra firma looked like the Swamp Thing. Every inch of his uniform and helmet was pasted with vines, leaves and grass.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Monroe Township Journal;
Neighbors Protesting Radio-Controlled Planes
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THEY love to fly, and it shows. Weather permitting, dozens of members of four radio-controlled airplane clubs show up each day at Thompson Park in an area set apart for the hobby nearly 25 years ago.

But in recent months, the long-simmering discontent of some neighbors has erupted in complaints to the Middlesex County Board of Chosen Freeholders. The residents contend that the operation of the planes in the park, which is owned and operated by the county, is producing unacceptable noise levels -- and threatening the safety of youngsters playing on nearby soccer fields.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sherrie L. Katz, Andrew Rosen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sherrie Lynne Katz, the daughter of Mrs. Marvin H. Berg of Moreland Hills, Ohio, and the late Dr. James B. Katz, was married yesterday evening to Andrew Scott Rosen, the son of Arlene and Edward Rosen of the Bronx. Rabbi Benjamin A. Kamin performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Cleveland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Documentaries, Two Different Takes on AIDS
nytimes_articles.abstract: To have AIDS is often to deny it. Lesions are covered up. Employers are told that nothing serious is wrong. It is a lie repeated to oneself as well: Life is not slipping away.   Perhaps all the more important, then, that along come two television documentaries about subjects who confront not just their own AIDS but also their imminent deaths. The two films are similar in themes -- each a video diary of the inexorable decline from AIDS. Yet they are opposites in tone -- one a relentless, brutal account of the ravages and humiliations of the disease by a pair of gay lovers; the other a spiritual, less graphic chronicle by a soft-spoken Canadian physician -- a kind of "Mister Rogers Explains AIDS" approach.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q and A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Roommates in a Co-op Question: I own a Manhattan co-op that for years was used only as a pied-a-terre by my immediate family and for visiting out-of-town friends and relatives. My daughter then occupied it for about a year with no problems. After she moved out last summer the building management refused access to my California cousin to whom I had lent my apartment for a month.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fighting on 2 Levels; AIDS Institute Chief Has Disease
nytimes_articles.abstract: Never mind that Nick Rango had just got out of the hospital. He propped his leg on a stool, remarking matter-of-factly at the swelling from blood clots. Then he pressed on with the meeting the other day in his Greenwich Village apartment, this one to review AIDS prevention programs.   None of his nine staff members at the session mentioned the matter outright, but an undercurrent ran through the meeting and all meetings Dr. Rango has these days: Nicholas A. Rango, this man who coordinates AIDS policy in New York State, has AIDS himself.

nytimes_articles.headline: Long Exodus Nears End for H.I.V.-Infected Refugees From Haiti
nytimes_articles.abstract: Frantz Lieumain considers himself one of the lucky ones. Were it not for a judge, he would still be with 142 other Haitian political refugees infected with the virus that causes AIDS, waiting in a camp at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba for a plane to take them to the United States.   Instead, Mr. Lieumain was one of about 50 H.I.V.-infected Haitian refugees who earlier this spring were brought to the United States for medical treatment on the orders of Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Federal District Court in Brooklyn. And he hopes to be at Miami International Airport to greet his friends and former tentmates when they start arriving here on Monday, less than a week after Judge Sterling expanded the order to include all those in Guantanamo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Karpov as Black: No More Mr. Draw
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANATOLY KARPOV used to be generous in agreeing to draws when he played Black, saving his attempts at winning for his turns with White. So, the former world champion won tournament after tournament by half-point margins without suffering a defeat.   Lately, he has opted for a more strenuous strategy that includes playing for victory as Black. This gives him greater margins of victory, but he loses a game now and then.

nytimes_articles.headline: SANTERIA FAITHFUL HAIL COURT RULING
nytimes_articles.abstract: For six years, ever since the City Council outlawed animal sacrifices to discourage the opening of a Santeria church here, Enoelia Martinez has been nervous about the future of her store, where she sells religious articles. But when she heard Friday that the Supreme Court had unanimously declared the city ordinances unconstitutional, her fears evaporated.   "This is very good for me," she said as she stood behind the counter of her shop, Botanica La Luz. The shop is just down the street from the empty lot whose purchase by the Church of Lukumi Babalu Aye set in motion the case that has established that First Amendment freedoms extend to the rituals of the Afro-Caribbean religion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shriver and Garrison Get in On-Court Spat
nytimes_articles.abstract: An on-court flareup between PAM SHRIVER and ZINA GARRISON-JACKSON yesterday overshadowed their quarterfinal match at the Edgbaston tournament in Birmingham, England, which Garrison-Jackson won, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2. During the match, played on an indoor court because rain made the grass courts unplayable, Shriver fired the ball at Garrison-Jackson and swore at her opponent's fans.   "She acted like a bitch," Garrison-Jackson said. "I couldn't believe that she didn't get a warning." Garrison said that she was sure Shriver was "a good person at heart."

nytimes_articles.headline: Gone Fishin': A Father, a Daughter, a Dingy and a Pair of Fluke
nytimes_articles.abstract: The tides that sweep through Jones Beach Inlet carry with them a spectacular array of wildlife, each in its season. In summer, there are ducks and geese, stripers and blues, egrets and herons. In fall these warm weather residents head south and the patient observer will sometimes glimpse dolphins and whales. In winter, Canada geese and harbor seals frequent the marshy islands of Long Island's Great South Bay and Hempstead Bay, yielding in spring to blackfish, flounder and fluke.   Mike McLaughlin is second-in-command at Ed's Fishing station, a white clapboard snack bar/boat livery/ tackle shop in Point Lookout, L.I., on the western shore of Jones Beach Inlet. Mack was born in the Bronx, summered in Point Lookout, served in Danang during the Tet offensive, left the Army but stayed in Vietnam with Chase Manhattan, took a Vietnamese bride, and on his return, knocked around the Northeast until the tides finally beached him at Ed's.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Are The Cukors?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In describing "boy" and "girl" movies  [ "The Great Divide: The Sexes at the Movies," May 23 ] , Suzanna Andrews is really kind to men. I went to the movies two or three times a week as a kid. Now I can hardly find five a year that don't make me ill. Part of the problem is that there are no directors like George Cukor, who thought women were fascinating and wonderful. Male directors have tapped into the pornography of violence so dear to young men's hearts.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Picture-Perfect Day, a Norman Rockwell Museum Opens
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sun was shining brightly, of course. The sky was blue and the weather was temperate. There were Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, Kiwanians and Rotarians, antique fire engines and a four-clown band. It was an all-American day. A Norman Rockwell day.   The occasion was a giant slice of mom and apple pie served up to the nation today at the grand opening of the Norman Rockwell Museum, a $9.2 million complex on 36 acres overlooking the Housatonic River. The site is about two miles from Main Street in Stockbridge, the picture-postcard Berkshire town where Rockwell lived and worked from 1953 until his death on Nov. 8, 1978.

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Lawyer at Closing? It Depends on Where
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE way residential real estate transactions have been conducted in South Jersey for more than a century is facing a legal challenge.

In the northern part of the state, lawyers customarily conduct closings; in the south, their involvement is optional. (It is generally believed that the practices followed those in the nearest big cities, the north emulating New York City custom, the south, Philadelphia's.) The debate is likely to go all the way to the state Supreme Court.

nytimes_articles.headline: Juliette White, Jeffrey Hyson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Juliette Darling White, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. White of New York, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Nugent Hyson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Hyson of Berwyn, Pa. The Rev. Dorsey W. M. McConnell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College in New London.   Mrs. Hyson, 25, is a development assistant for the College of Arts and Sciences at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y. She and her husband graduated from Yale University. Her father is the founder and the president of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. Her mother, Elizabeth D. White, is a theatrical producer in New York and a jewelry maker in New York and Waterford.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
A Gallery Makes Its Debut
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ART doesn't have a permanent zip code," Joseph Szoecs declares. He explains that art used to be centered in Rome, then Paris and later New York, so why not Jersey City? Mr. Szoecs has a five-year lease on a former machine shop he recently converted into the Trans Hudson Gallery, and he says that making Jersey City synonymous with the best in contemporary art is his goal.

 To carry out his vision, he has mounted as his first show a large and varied group exhibition called "Fusion." The title furthers what the gallery's name portends, that he is taking art from both sides of the river. The show is two-thirds New Jersey and one-third New York City, but precise numbers are not the point. Mr. Szoecs (pronounced search) notes that his artists come from many places -- Hungary, Sweden and California, for example -- and happen to live on either bank of the Hudson. (Mr. Szoecs himself is originally from Hungary.)

nytimes_articles.headline: Johnson Just as Bad Second Time Around
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sequel to Jeff Johnson's first horror show of 1993 was just as frightful for the Yankees tonight. Five days after the pitcher was pummeled in his season debut, he duplicated the abominable start by being routed for five runs again and not lasting beyond the second inning again.   Johnson's 45-pitch fiasco allowed the Brewers to rush to an early cushion, cruise to a 9-1 victory over the Yankees at County Stadium and end their three-game losing streak. The disastrous outing likely ended Johnson's sixth stint in the majors. Manager Buck Showalter was hesitant to even give the left-hander his second start and hinted strongly that Johnson would be demoted to the minor leagues Sunday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kitty Weyl, Robert Dove
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nancy Katherine Weyl, a senior public affairs manager for the United States Chamber of Commerce in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Wallace Dove, a managing director in New York for UBS Securities, an investment bank. The Rev. Campbell Gillon performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Fox Folly Farm in Lincoln, Va., the weekend home of the bride's mother.    Mrs. Dove, 35, is known as Kitty. She graduated from Colby College. She is the daughter of Nancy S. Weyl of McLean, Va., and the late Dr. W. Leonard Weyl. Her father was the chief of surgery at Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital in Arlington. Her mother is a novelist and a painter.

nytimes_articles.headline: In a Pink Sequined Straitjacket
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TIME REMAINING
By James McCourt.
273 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

nytimes_articles.headline: A la Carte; The Wheel of Fortune Spins Out AuthenticFare
nytimes_articles.abstract: THERE is no chow mein, chop suey, egg roll or egg foo young at the exceptional new Fortune Wheel seafood restaurant in Levittown.   The familiar menu mainstays are considered gimmicky Americanized Chinese dishes by both Asian and Western purists. Those aficionados flock to the Fortune Wheel because it is the real thing.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Canada's Race for Premier, Front-Runner Falters
nytimes_articles.abstract: A few months back it looked pretty certain that Canada was about to get its first woman as Prime Minister, a cello-playing lawyer from Vancouver named Kim Campbell, who at 46 is the same age as President Clinton.   But when 3,850 Progressive Conservative delegates start voting on Sunday at their leadership convention here the glamorous former Justice Minister, who was once photographed bare-shouldered behind her legal robes, will feel the pressure from a folksy 34-year-old man from a small town in Quebec named Jean Charest.

nytimes_articles.headline: Zachary Young and Nancy Paula Tabs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nancy Paula Tabs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tabs of New York was married yesterday evening to Zachary Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Young of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Gluck performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in New York.   Ms. Tabs, 25, is keeping her name. She is a senior property underwriter for the ITT Hartford Insurance Company in New York. She graduated cum laude from Brandeis University. Her father is the executive vice president of finance of Fortunoff, the retail chain, in Westbury, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Crooning Game
nytimes_articles.abstract: SOMETHING on the plate is moving. There among the crisp greens, the handsome radishes and carrots and the proud trio of freshly fried samosas, served among the careful opulence of this fine midtown Indian restaurant, is a little black speck, no bigger than the head of a pin, and Chris Isaak doesn't like it. No sir, he doesn't like it one bit. The pompadoured, button-nosed, 36-year-old singer focuses his sharp blue eyes on the offending speck. He leans in closer, then he turns his gaze upon the waiter, who has just deposited the plate and now stands expectantly at the table.   "Hey!" Mr. Isaak says. "This little guy's still alive."

nytimes_articles.headline: Brazilian Goes Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: Saying he was too upset to continue in a preview to the 1994 World Cup, the Brazilian soccer player JULIO CESAR returned home after $150,000 in cash and watches were stolen from his hotel room, a team spokesman said yesterday. While Brazil played Germany to a 3-3 tie Thursday in the U.S. Cup '93 at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington, someone was taking cash and valuables from both teams' hotel rooms.   Two other Brazilian players -- CARECA and VALBER -- lost a total of $8,300 in thefts at the team's hotel in Silver Spring, Md., the spokesman, FRANCISCO MARCOS, said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Traveling Tightwads: How Low to Go?
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT is it about travel that turns people into raving cheapskates? I have nothing against getting a discount; in fact, my epitaph will probably be, "She got a cheap fare." But some tourists seem to spend their entire vacation playing the wayfarer's version of "The Price Is Right." It matters not if a given experience is momentous, breathtaking, romantic, educational -- or unpleasant. What matters is the price.    Obviously, if you've got a wandering soul and limited funds, it's better to go on the proverbial shoestring than not to go at all. But bargain hunters can get obsessive. Last year, for example, my husband, Duke, and I went to Ecuador, a destination we admittedly chose because an airline was offering a $430 round-trip special from Los Angeles to Guayaquil. The country has to be one of the least expensive places in the Western Hemisphere -- we regularly dined well for under $10, flew between major cities for $16 and took private Spanish lessons at a Quito school for $5 an hour. Still we were called extravagant.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hoping to Reclaim a Page From His Past
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the first round of this week's 93d United States Open at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J., approaches, Jack Nicklaus is hoping that rekindled memories of some of his best golf ever will help him produce the best that he has left.   No theater in golf has illuminated the Nicklaus legend more than Baltusrol's Lower Course. The last two times the Open was held over the arduous A. W. Tillinghast-designed layout, Nicklaus won by breaking the championship 72-hole scoring record.

nytimes_articles.headline: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: PRODUCTIVITY THEME   A conference on enhancing productivity, profitability and financial stability is to be held Friday from 8 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. at the Marriott Hotel, 670 White Plains Road in Tarrytown, organized by the Westchester County Association.   "Improving Your Bottom Line: Innovative Strategies and Techniques" is the title of the program, and it is aimed at corporations, nonprofit organizations and government agencies. A light breakfast, lunch and printed materials are included in the fee of $60.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DINING OUT;
On the Streets of Italy in Port Chester
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RATINGS can be deceiving; they often cannot be applied across the board. In recent weeks we've written about a number of restaurants whose ratings reflect the average of some well-crafted dishes and some duds. Per Voi is another spot that exhibits such unevenness. We would come here again, however, for its good service, singular decor and pasta; we would avoid entrees and fancy-sounding specials. 

While some will see the decor as a set for a low-budget opera, others will enjoy the alfresco quality and whimsy of the Marketplace lined with "shops" drawn like cartoons. They are displayed behind a charming variety of recycled windows and doors, which, together with the steps and handrails leading to them, add a realistic touch. Painted on a high ceiling as though pipes and ducts didn't exit, sky and clouds promise perennial good weather, and strings of miniature lights recall the illumination on many Italian streets.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Blizzard
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: In the Blizzard of '93, my husband and I were safe at home in Connecticut. However, last summer we had a "stranded passenger" experience that proved how accommodating an airline can be.   In July, my husband and I and our 13-year-old grandson boarded a United flight at La Guardia for Boise, Idaho. We were to stop in Denver, and as we approached, an announcement came that the city was experiencing severe thunderstorms and our flight would terminate there.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where the Clothes Match the Music
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN SoHo's deepest heartland, on Spring Street near West Broadway, 100 percent polyester double-knit shirts are being snapped up by 23-year-olds for $74 apiece. "They're very 'Mambo Kings,' very retro," said Joseph Melendez, the manager of Union, the 300-square-foot shop that throbbed with hip-hop music on a recent Friday afternoon.    Union also carries regulation blue nylon mail-carrier jackets with U.S. Mail patches ($110) and shapeless brown shirts with the yellow logo of the United Parcel Service ($42): "American work wear, utility kind of stuff," said James Jebbia, an owner.

nytimes_articles.headline: Characters From Books Captivate Young Readers
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE grounds of Westchester Community College usually welcome a diverse group of students -- but on a recent Saturday the campus was invaded by an especially young population. Whether pushed in a stroller, carried on a father's shoulder or clinging tightly to a mother's hand, the county's children were out in full force.    Despite unseasonably chilly weather and stormy skies that dumped rain throughout the day, it seemed as if every parent who had a child under 12 had turned out for the first children's literature festival, Happily Ever After, on June 5.

nytimes_articles.headline:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Block Island, R.I.;
Rescuing Wetlands
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THREE conservation groups have rescued from development a 4.27-acre grassy knoll on this island of 820 year-round residents that had been ticketed for luxury housing during the 80's building boom.

The parcel, off Beach Avenue near the Great Salt Pond on the eastern end of this resort island about 10 miles from mainland Rhode Island, was purchased for $220,000 by The Nature Conservancy, the Block Island Land Trust and the Block Island Conservancy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Baseball Brawl With a Difference
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   The outrageous 20-minute brawl on June 6 between the Baltimore Orioles and the Seattle Mariners should not be taken lightly. Umpire Durwood Merrill called it the worst melee between two teams that he had seen in 17 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ending Torture Isn't Colonialism
nytimes_articles.abstract: It turns history upside down when third-world countries, long the victims of colonialist oppression, chop away at the liberating principles of human rights. But that is exactly what's happened in preparation for the World Conference on Human Rights, which opens in Vienna tomorrow. So deep are divisions over the universality of human rights, a concept some belittle as excessively "Western," that delegates could not agree on condemning torture in their draft declaration.    Prodded by China and Indonesia, 40 Asian countries approved a statement contending that standards of justice and fairness should be tempered by "regional peculiarities and various historical, cultural and religious backgrounds." The statement adds that human rights should never be used as "an instrument of political pressure" or made a condition for development aid. Going further, 41 African states say their right to such aid is absolute.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Capitol Hill, a Top Aide With No Belief in Age Limits
nytimes_articles.abstract: Even the baby-boomer White House, awash with aides under 30 years old, has few who can rival Henry Ellenbogen, the Boy Wonder of Capitol Hill.   At age 20, he hasn't yet completed his senior year as a history and science major at Harvard University, but as administrative assistant to a Florida Congressman, he manages a $1 million budget, supervises a staff of 17 and holds a job that usually requires at least 10 years experience in Congressional affairs.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Broker in Human Lives
nytimes_articles.abstract: SPY TRADER Germany's Devil's Advocate and the Darkest Secrets of the Cold War. By Craig R. Whitney. Illustrated. 375 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. $25.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in the Long Island Weekly on May 30 about the cancellation of Author's Day at the Sag Harbor Elementary School referred incorrectly to the school's arrangements with Kate McMullan, author of "The Noisy Giants' Tea Party," and Jean Marzollo, writer of 60 books. The authors did not receive a fee.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Stuff That Plays Are Made Of
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anna Deavere Smith has been honing her new one-woman show, "Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992" up until the last minute. The play, whose subject is the Los Angeles riots, is a follow-up to "Fires in the Mirror," her critically praised 1992 show at the Joseph Papp Public Theater in New York.    Ms. Smith creates her works by interviewing people about a particular topic. Then using their own words, she brings each individual to life on stage.

nytimes_articles.headline: A View of the Water Whets the Appetite
nytimes_articles.abstract: SHINING water, bobbing boats and spectacular sunsets are the floor show at East Hampton Point, this season's most talked-about new restaurant.   This East Hampton newcomer might have the Island's best water views. Certainly it ranks in the top three, along with Starr Boggs in Westhampton Beach and the Crescent in Bayville.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Search for Pine Barrens Money
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AS legislation to preserve 50,000 acres of Long Island pine barrens forever was introduced last week in Albany, officials, builders and environmentalists agreed last week that without a commitment of millions of dollars to buy land and for other costs, all that has been gained in months of talks may evaporate.

The bill would create a five-member commission to enforce preservation in the 100,000 remaining acres of pine barrens in Brookhaven, Riverhead and Southampton. The mainly undeveloped expanse is a critical watershed and the remnant of a rare ecosystem dominated by scrub oaks and pitch pines.

nytimes_articles.headline: Three Marriages, Three Worlds, Three Acts
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONCE, maybe 20 years ago, Alan Ayckbourn was commonly called the English Neil Simon. Now that the one has surpassed the other in prolificacy (Ayckbourn: 45, Simon: 26) and sheer comic invention, the comparison is less than glib, more than fatuous and to steal a deconstruction from Shakespeare's Dogberry, completely odorous. Besides, while Mr. Simon, now and again, reaches for depth, or lets in the darkness, it is one of the ego, not the soul.    Such old associations are brought to mind by the Long Wharf Theater's revival of Mr. Ayckbourn's "Absurd Person Singular," almost 19 years after the play's Broadway premiere. True to the manner of the playwright's playful setups -- in Ayckbourn, relationships and life unravel -- the story unravels in three kitchens in three acts over three Christmases: the last one, this one and the next one.

nytimes_articles.headline: Eileen Brennan, John Conlon Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eileen Doran Brennan, an associate at the law firm of Burke Horan & Macri, was married yesterday to John Matthew Conlon Jr., an associate at the law firm of Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCloy, both in New York. The Rev. Patrick A. Walsh performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Tuckahoe, N.Y.   The bride graduated from the College of the Holy Cross. She and her husband, both 29, received law degrees from Fordham University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Brennan Jr. of Eastchester, N.Y. The bride's father is a lawyer for the Hearst Corporation in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Uffizi Gallery Reopening Set For Next Week
nytimes_articles.abstract: After the car bomb explosion that blasted through the Uffizi Gallery in Florence on May 27, the city authorities are now hoping to reopen part of it on June 20.   On that day visitors will be able to enter the east wing of the gallery -- relatively undamaged in the explosion -- that is home to the museum's unrivaled collection of Botticellis and other Italian works from the 13th-century Giotto to 16th-century artists.

nytimes_articles.headline: Busy Evenings in a City of Causes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Warm spring weather finds New Yorkers turning out to help the homeless, fight AIDS, recognize achievement and celebrate fine craftsmanship.

nytimes_articles.headline: Haitians Mourn the Loss of a Piece of Their Dream
nytimes_articles.abstract: Wilner Boucicault died living the American dream, shot down as he closed his furniture store, the largest Haitian-owned business in New York City, perhaps the entire country. To many of his countrymen struggling through life in a new land, he was the embodiment of what they were working to become and a source of help and advice on how to attain success in an unfamiliar country.   Mr. Boucicault arrived in New York 25 years ago from a suburb outside Port-au-Prince and worked as a parking attendant while he studied at the City University, an incubator of generations of immigrant success stories. Saving his money, he opened his store only a year ago, and he ultimately wanted to own a bank that would serve the needs of other Haitian-Americans.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Jazz Festival and Its Musical Muses; Lena Horne -- A Majestic Vessel, a Proffered Wink
nytimes_articles.abstract: The 1993 JVC Jazz Festival, which runs from Friday to June 26, will be sleeker than in previous years. With 20 concerts at six locations throughout Manhattan, the schedule is heavy in singers and tributes (to the likes of Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker). And because of rising costs, many smaller events, like the afternoon piano concerts, have been dropped. But despite the leanness, the festival should still offer performances to satisfy the tastes of most jazz lovers. Here, six noted authors tell why a performer or honoree on this year's program speaks to them.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Are They Training For?
nytimes_articles.abstract: YOU know who they are.   You're heaving your way through your ninth minute on the Stairmaster, wondering exactly how humiliating it would be to pass out in front of a roomful of people on the way to the drinking fountain. Glancing up for a gulp of oxygen, you see them: the ones who work out three to four hours without breaking a sweat.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: SPORTS MEMOIR WILLIE'S GAME An Autobiography. By Willie Mosconi and Stanley Cohen. Macmillan, $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sarah L. Clark, Robert A. Stuart
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sarah Louise Clark, a daughter of Warren Clark Jr. of Washington and Alice S. Ritchie of Chestertown, Md., was married yesterday to Robert Andrew Stuart, a son of August D. Stuart of Killington, Vt., and Marian R. Stuart of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Roger P. Butts performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Paul's Church, Kent, in Chestertown.   Mrs. Clark Stuart, 34, is a scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund in New York. She graduated from Pomona College and received a master's degree in forestry and environmental studies from Yale University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jacqueline Wein, Thomas LaMacchia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jacqueline Sara Wein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Wein of Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas F. LaMacchia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. LaMacchia of Cincinnati. The Rev. James Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (L.I.) Country Club.   The bride and the bridegroom, both 26, graduated from Princeton University.   Ms. Wein, who is keeping her name, was until recently the membership coordinator for Opera America, a service organization in Washington for North American opera companies. Her father is an engineer in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wendy Dubin, Brooks Bitterman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Wendy Dubin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan L. Dubin of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Brooks Bitterman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bitterman of New York. Margaretha Birknes, a justice of the peace in South Dartmouth, Mass., performed the ceremony at the bride's home there.    Ms. Dubin, a potter and a freelance writer, is keeping her name. She graduated from Barnard College and received master's degrees in art history from Columbia University and in artisanry from the University of Massachusetts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gwendolyn Grant, Steven Bowers
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Gwendolyn Grant and Dr. Steven Malcolm Bowers, both physicians at Yale-New Haven Hospital, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Lowell Ballinger, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Old Parish Church in Weston, Vt.   The bride, 33, is a resident in internal medicine. She graduated from Amherst College and the Yale School of Medicine. She is a daughter of Jenifer Grant of New Haven and Dr. John P. Grant Jr. of New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Media Feed
nytimes_articles.abstract:
It is a measure of the diminished self-esteem of this Administration that insiders no longer talk about having a good year, or a good month or even a good week. They're looking for a few good days. Last week they finally got five in a row. I happened to be there, and here's how they did it.

Monday: In his debut as the President's new counselor, David Gergen shows up in the press room to announce his decision to "turn the page" on 12:30 press briefings, which will hereafter be conducted at the more convenient time of 11:30. The announcement sends a shot of electricity through the room, as several reporters rush to the phones to make lunch reservations. Then, with great fanfare, Gergen cuts a red ribbon reopening the back offices to the press. Access-starved reporters surge forward into the previously off-limits back corridor, where a buffet of cold cuts and cheese cubes has been set up to welcome us. A string quartet plays in the background as we fan out to buttonhole press staffers we haven't seen since the election.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I felt very lucky that I had a skill and I didn't have to be a burden on the government. I could just carve out my own little corner in the United States, and sew and sew until the kids here were legal and the kids I left at home didn't need me anymore." -- LEIDA FERMIN, who runs a small illegal sewing factory in Manhattan.  [ 42:1. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: The Gift of a Difficult Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: ORDINARY TIME Cycles in Marriage, Faith, and Renewal. By Nancy Mairs. 238 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unconventional College Finds Adults Are Good Students
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT Charter Oak State College in Connecticut there are no classrooms and no curriculum. It does have a faculty but its members don't teach. Ten percent of its students -- average age close to 40 -- live outside the state. Some even live outside the country. The college has no campus, but exists in a suite of rooms in a commercial office and shopping complex. It is a most unusual place.   It is also relatively unknown. Ask most people about Charter Oak and they might talk about the tree revered in early Connecticut history, where the colony's charter was hidden. But a college?

nytimes_articles.headline: No Excuses, No Solace As Big Names Stumble
nytimes_articles.abstract: Curtis Strange, Paul Azinger and Seve Ballesteros head into next week's United States Open under less than ideal circumstances after their showing at this week's Buick Classic.   These three, along with several other prominent players on the PGA Tour like John Daly, performed miserably in this week's tournament at the Westchester Country Club and missed the cut.

nytimes_articles.headline: Made-for-TV Mystery: What, if Anything, Do Yanks Owe City?
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is the biggest and most secretive television deal in local team sports history, one the New York Yankees and the Madison Square Garden Network discuss as openly as Coca-Cola executives discuss their soda formula. So shrouded is this deal that when New York City auditors wanted to view it, they were refused copies, and had to trek to Yankee Stadium like obsequious subjects doing their master's bidding.   "I've been trying to find out what the cable deal is for years," said Betsy Gotbaum, New York City's Parks Commissioner, whose department administers Yankee and Shea Stadiums and is responsible for collecting rent from the teams.

nytimes_articles.headline: Meditations on the Epidemic
nytimes_articles.abstract: MONOPOLIES OF LOSS By Adam Mars-Jones. 250 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

nytimes_articles.headline: Spielberg Grapples With the Horror Of the Holocaust
nytimes_articles.abstract: At a railway siding, a Nazi commandant and his servile lieutenants feast on fruit and drink punch from a crystal bowl while hundreds of terrified Jews -- penned in stifling cattle cars -- beseech their captors for water.   Sixty miles from Auschwitz, near the site where this horror unfolded a half century ago, Steven Spielberg was directing this scene from "Schindler's List." Based on the acclaimed 1982 book by Thomas Keneally, the film tells the story of a vain German businessman, Oskar Schindler, who saved the lives of his 1,300 Jewish factory workers at the height of the Holocaust.

nytimes_articles.headline: Demonstrations By the Masters
nytimes_articles.abstract: MORE than 100 years after Longfellow wrote his poem celebrating the village blacksmith, no fewer than 11 blacksmiths will bend and twist red-hot iron this summer at the Peters Valley Craft Center. They will show their students how to form Colonial-style hardware and candelabra in the early 19th-century forge.    In other studios, potters, fiber artists, woodworkers and jewelry makers will demonstrate traditional and innovative methods for creating contemporary crafts. Peters Valley is offering 70 workshops this summer.

nytimes_articles.headline: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: New York Hotels; New York City Hotels Battling the Blues
nytimes_articles.abstract: SEVERAL years ago, when Regent Hotels International decided to put up a 52-story luxury hotel at 57 East 57th Street, it seemed like a great idea. The New York economy was booming, hotels were commanding impressive room rates, and occupancy rates were high.    By last August, when the Four Seasons bought all the Regent properties, New York wasn't such a boom town anymore. The Four Seasons professed to be unworried. After all, the company, whose Pierre Hotel has been astriking success, would have its name emblazoned on a luxury property.

nytimes_articles.headline: Paris Airports Get Direct Link
nytimes_articles.abstract: Travel between Orly Airport south of Paris and Charles de Gaulle Airport at Roissy in the northeast can be completed entirely by rail and without getting into delays caused by city traffic. The Orlyval light rail automated train connects Orly South and Orly West terminals with the suburban R.E.R. B line at the Antony stop.   The two trains are on either side of the same platform and one usually leaves promptly after the other arrives.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Group Offers to Help the Ill Commit Suicide
nytimes_articles.abstract: A number of right-to-die advocates here have created what is apparently the nation's first organization intended to provide professionals who will help terminally ill people kill themselves.   It is unclear whether the organization's efforts violate the laws of Washington State, where the "promoting" of suicide has been illegal for almost two decades.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lee White, Sergio Galvis
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary Lee White was married yesterday to Sergio Jordan Galvis, like her, a lawyer in New York. The Rev. John F. Halborg officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.   The bride, who is known as Lee, is an associate in the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts who works in the counsel's office of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She graduated summa cum laude from Princeton University and received a law degree from Columbia University.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Than Merely Pop
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Regarding Edward Rothstein's essay "Beyond CD: Music Takes a Back Seat"  [ May 16 ] , I should like to note that the repertory of the world's most celebrated classical musicians is represented on DCC. Further, with more than 101 titles currently available in the United States on DCC and with an additional 23 titles scheduled for release before the end of the year, Polygram Classics and Jazz (representing the London, Deutsche Grammophon and Philips Classics labels) is very definitely committed to this new digital sound carrier.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lauren Ashburn and Paul Dueffert
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lauren Elizabeth Ashburn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Ashburn of Wyomissing Hills, Pa., was married yesterday to Paul Keith Dueffert, the son of Shirley M. Dueffert of Waconia, Minn., and the late Orville Dueffert. The Rev. Anthony Mongiello, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Memorial Chapel at Albright College in Reading, Pa.   Ms. Ashburn, 25, is keeping her name. She is a news assistant at New York 1 News in New York. She graduated from Albright and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University. Her father is the senior vice president of Kelly Michener Inc., an advertising agency in Lancaster, Pa. Her mother, Ellen Ashburn, is the director of reading and language arts for the Reading Public School District.

nytimes_articles.headline: Therapist Puts Twist On Tales of the Soul
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Amy Bloom is a presence: statuesque and poised, with dark almond eyes topped by strong, arched eyebrows, her luminous face framed by a raven bob.

She speaks in a velvety contralto that a diva might envy, a voice graced by intelligence, wit and candor. She looks and sounds like someone born to be in the limelight. The surprise is that she has chosen to avoid it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Albany Pressured to Draw Plans to Reduce Pollution
nytimes_articles.abstract: Imagine the impact on New York City traffic if large stretches of the Gowanus Expressway, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, and the Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges had to be shut down because there was no longer money for repairs.   That's the nightmare that state officials are depicting to prod the Legislature into enacting a plan that would meet the requirements of the Federal Clean Air Act before the current legislative session is scheduled to end June 25. Failure to do so could cost the state billions in roadway repair dollars.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jackson Leaves The Hunt For Hunted
nytimes_articles.abstract: Darrin Jackson left a defending World Series champion, a team two games out of first place in its division. He joined the second-worst team in baseball, a club so far down in the standing, it would take an amazing run just to get out of last place.   He says he's happy about it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Whistle Silenced, Cityspire Sales Resume
nytimes_articles.abstract: CITYSPIRE, the 73-story tower at 150 West 56th Street, is known for many things, not all of them flattering.   It was built taller than zoning rules allowed. It was supposed to have an arcade and rehearsal studio, which were never built. Then, it began to whistle so loudly that people 10 blocks away lost sleep on windy nights.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Mandate Grows
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations has expanded its mandate in peacekeeping operations with its attack on a Somali faction leader who is accused of killing Pakistani peacekeepers. But the action raises troubling questions about whether United Nations efforts must depend on United States firepower.    News analysis, page 16.

nytimes_articles.headline: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
nytimes_articles.abstract: HOW WE SURVIVED COMMUNISM AND EVEN LAUGHED By Slavenka Drakulic. Harper Perennial, $12. A Croatian journalist discusses life under Communism; it was filled with indignities large and small, from the lack of privacy to the lack of panty hose. Last year our reviewer, Cathy Young, called the book a "thoughtful, beautifully written collection."

nytimes_articles.headline: When Tour Groups Face Changing of the Guide
nytimes_articles.abstract: AN expert guide or star lecturer is often the selling point for a tour. It is sometimes a dicey one: the expert may fall ill or for another reason be unable to go.    When this happens, what is the responsibility of the travel company selling the trip? And what are the rights of the traveler? These questions, among the many that unfold in the chasm between a brochure and an actual trip, have tangled answers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; A Political Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: Discussions of political correctness on campus always puzzle me a bit, because they usually have as their starting point a view of the academy, in fact the world, that is contrary to established reality. That is, that into this calm pool of egalitarian rational discourse comes the bigfoot of racial and gender politics, ready to stomp down anyone who offends, diverges, challenges liberal orthodoxy.    The stomping part I understand. But that calm egalitarian pool? Oh, phooey, boys and girls.

nytimes_articles.headline: Device Makes Drunken Drivers Nonstarters
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A Manhattan bicyclist was dragged eight blocks after having been hit by a drunken driver, whose license had been repeatedly suspended and who was forbidden to drive (news article, June 1).    A technological development promises to reduce the problem of drunken driving by those who have lost their licenses: the ignition interlock device. Attached to a car's ignition, this miniaturized "breathalyzer" prevents the car from being started if the driver "blows" too high an alcohol reading. Circumvention seems less a problem than was feared, and there is reason to believe that the basic drinking habits of drivers may be altered.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Blizzard
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: I read the words of the disgruntled travelers in the Blizzard of '93 (Letters to the Editor, May 16) and felt I must show the other side.   Five of us, my sister, my daughter and two granddaughters and I, were traveling east from Salt Lake City on Saturday, March 13. My sister and I were changing planes in Chicago and then going on to Newburgh, N.Y. We were told we would get no farther than Chicago and when we arrived we should check with personnel there for information about a hotel room. My daughter and her two children were to change in Chicago for Syracuse.

nytimes_articles.headline: Leigh Weatherly, Anthony Flint
nytimes_articles.abstract: Leigh Manning Weatherly, a daughter of Michael M. Weatherly of Southport, Conn., and Eloise J. Weatherly of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Anthony Evans Flint, the son of George S. Flint of New York and Mary Alice Flint of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.   Ms. Weatherly, 29, is keeping her name. She is an editor at Academic Press in Cambridge, Mass., a subsidiary of Harcourt Brace. She graduated from Boston University. Her father is a founder of the Forschner Group Inc., an importer and distributor of Swiss Army products in Shelton, Conn.

nytimes_articles.headline:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Tales of the Vienna Streets
nytimes_articles.abstract: An insightful photographic portrait, VIENNA 1850-1930: Architecture (Rizzoli, $65) provides a panorama of Viennese architecture during an era when the city was one of the most important intellectual and cultural centers in Europe. An essay by Peter Haiko, an architectural historian who teaches at the University of Vienna, provides a competent and accessible introduction to the historical events and theoretical issues for those unfamiliar with the architecture of the period. The heart of the book, however, is the fine color and black-and-white photographs of more than 30 structures documenting the metamorphosis of Vienna from a Baroque capital draped in the mantle of historicist styles to the stern, uncompromising forms of the modern city. In addition to civic and religious structures, the building types surveyed include private villas, apartment buildings and municipal structures like gasworks, water towers and bridges. Like the finest examples of human portraiture, Roberto Schezen's photographs reveal character as well as physiognomy. While his treatment of facades and major interior spaces conveys the public decorum and grand scale of urban architecture, his photographs of building details and eccentric spaces reveal intriguing facets of his subjects. Mr. Schezen possesses a wonderful eye for decorative details. The result is an unusually subtle and nuanced description of architecture. This photographic paean to Vienna vividly testifies to architecture's ability to transcend the requirements of mere shelter and evoke the spirit of an age and the character of a place.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alpha  $126,800   745 Pursel Street  3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 56-year-old ranch; covered back porch, move-in condition, full basement; taxes $2,664. Colonia  $160,000   37 North Lincoln Avenue  3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 37-year-old split level; new roof and water heater, parquet floors, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,411. Greenwich Township  $158,000   129 Warren Street  4-bedroom, 3-bath, 6-year-old bi-level; 2 acres plus, c/a; taxes $2,769. Iselin  $83,000   207 Woodbridge Commons  2-bedroom, 1-bath, 10-year-old condominium apartment; c/a, covered patio, monthly maintenance $125; taxes $2,084. Lopatcong  $130,000   47 Peddlers Lane  4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old bi-level; newly painted interior, c/a, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $5,800. Milltown  $152,500   63 Townsend Street  3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; new roof and siding, eat-in-kitchen, full basement; taxes $2,850.  OTHER AREAS  Mamaroneck, N.Y.  $260,000   3 Washington Square  3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old co-op; entry hall, dining room, modern kitchen, terrace, doorman, beach rights; maintenance $993. Avon, Conn.  $211,000   30 Hemlock Lane  3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old contemporary; screened porch, new deck, on cul de sac, 1 acre; taxes $4,480. Bayport, L.I.  $135,000  319 Fairview Avenue  3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, den, finished basement, fireplace; taxes $5,700.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss McGibbon, Dr. Maccaro
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth McGibbon, a registered nurse at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhassett, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Paul C. Maccaro, a chief resident in the department of medicine there. The Rev. Jose R. Aldegunde performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Incarnation in Queens Village, Queens.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. to Push Germany and Japan for U.N. Council
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration has told Germany and Japan it will soon start a campaign to fulfill its promise to support permanent seats for them on the Security Council.   Despite the Administration's position, diplomats said any effort to change the Security Council would run into difficulties. Britain and France, for instance, worry about losing their permanent seats and veto privileges.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Moncrieff, Mr. Buttrick
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lucinda Barrett Moncrieff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Van Dyke Moncrieff of Wickford, R.I., was married yesterday to Samuel Cox Buttrick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stedman Buttrick of Concord, Mass. The Rev. Mary Carson performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church in Newport, R.I.    Mrs. Buttrick was until recently an institutional equity sales assistant at the First Boston Corporation in New York. Her father, now retired, was a vice president at Bowne & Company, financial printers in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Why Not More Safety In Car Inspections?
nytimes_articles.abstract: I read with interest your May 23d article about Connecticut's success in selling special interest license plates. Fine! But there is another side of our Department of Motor Vehicle activity which is woefully inadequate: car inspections.   Connecticut does test annually for emissions. But there is no mandatory testing for lights or brakes. I talked to my representative and senator about this and was told to contact Commissioner Goldberg. His reply to me was that nothing could be changed without an act of the legislature.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Computers Could Link Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract:
REGARDLESS of the outcome of a metropolitan Hartford school desegregation lawsuit, black, white and Hispanic children from the suburbs and the city may soon find themselves collaborating on homework assignments, talking back and forth computer to computer.

Connecticut's test project, using computers, telephone lines and video equipment so children can see one another, is expected to involve elementary school students from Morley School in West Hartford and Annie Fisher School in Hartford, two racially and economically different neighborhoods.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brooke Silbersack and John Aymar 3d
nytimes_articles.abstract: Brooke Claire Silbersack, the daughter of Virginia Rodgers of Stamford, Conn., and J. Wayne Silbersack of Darien, Conn., was married on Thursday to John vanBeuren Aymar 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aymar Jr. of Darien. The Rev. Winston Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Swept Away Resort in Negril, Jamaica.   Mrs. Aymar, 24, is a student at Fordham University. Her father, now retired, was a vice president of Petersen Advertising in Freehold, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Giuliani Finds Well-Wishers in Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dressed in red, khaki and blue and pressing the themes of crime, drugs and educational failure, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, traversed Queens yesterday with a promise to "straighten this city out" by increasing arrests of drug dealers, reducing crime and slashing the size of city government.   His trip marked one of his most extensive street campaign efforts to date, and drew a largely positive response in a borough that backed him with more than 60 percent of the vote in the 1989 election.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Jazz Festival and Its Musical Muses; Jimmy Scott -- A Voice That Tweaks Souls
nytimes_articles.abstract: The 1993 JVC Jazz Festival, which runs from Friday to June 26, will be sleeker than in previous years. With 20 concerts at six locations throughout Manhattan, the schedule is heavy in singers and tributes (to the likes of Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker). And because of rising costs, many smaller events, like the afternoon piano concerts, have been dropped. But despite the leanness, the festival should still offer performances to satisfy the tastes of most jazz lovers. Here, six noted authors tell why a performer or honoree on this year's program speaks to them.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Pushes for a Smoking Ban on Flights Abroad
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to complaints and new worries about the effect of second-hand smoke, the Clinton Administration is working to speed the day when smoking is banned on all international flights into and out of the United States.   Currently, United States airlines allow smoking on all international flights, except to Canada. An international agreement adopted by a United Nations agency urges that smoking be banned on all flights between countries by 1996, but it has no enforcement provisions. So the Administration has begun trying to negotiate regional or bilateral agreements that would ban smoking for passengers and crew members without putting United States airlines at a disadvantage.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Stamford, Before or After the Show
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Stamford Center for the Arts in downtown Stamford has proved a magnet, with various restaurants opening in the immediate vicinity over a very short period of time.   Directly across from the center is Peppino's Ristorante, which is handy for theatergoers who want to dine before or after a performance. In fact, on a performance night recently, the first question the friendly and helpful head waiter asked us was if we were going to the theater. We made the mistake of saying no, and consequently waited and waited for our first course while tables all around us were served briskly. It pays to be in a hurry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brian O'Donoghue, Madeline Cuomo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Madeline Cerise Cuomo, a daughter of Gov. and Mrs. Mario M. Cuomo of Albany and Holliswood, Queens, was married yesterday to Brian John O'Donoghue, a son of Justice and Mrs. James F. O'Donoghue of Bayside, Queens. Msgr. John L. Jones performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Albany.   Mrs. Cuomo-O'Donoghue, 28, is an associate at the New York law firm of Shea & Gould. She graduated from the State University at Albany and received her law degree from Albany Law School.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kollek's Last Run May Be Toughest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Not many months ago, when he was a mere 81 years old, Mayor Teddy Kollek allowed that he had become too old to run for office again and that he himself would not vote for someone with so much mileage on him.   Now, a few weeks past his 82d birthday and deep into his 28th year of dominating Jerusalem City Hall, Mr. Kollek has decided that he has enough steam left, after all, for one more hurrah.

nytimes_articles.headline: To Arms! To Arms! White Fly is Here
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE goal now is to keep the garden blooming through the sunny months. If all goes well, everything should be nearly weedless and trouble free. This does require a few extra hours outdoors, but all too often uninvited troubles appear. One of the most discouraging is white fly.   These tiny insect pests seem to appear out of nowhere, and almost every kind of soft succulent leaf is to their liking. They keep away from a few annuals like impatiens and begonias, but vegetable gardeners know this nuisance well, especially on squash and tomato plants.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Sunday; Doing Lunch, And Dinner, And the Dishes
nytimes_articles.abstract: THERE are 250 million Americans and every one is convinced he can run his own business, typically a restaurant. This upscale suburb has been so besieged, village officials recently declared an eight-month moratorium on new restaurants.   Too many were failing, leaving vacant storefronts. "People think anyone can open a restaurant," said Nick Falcone, co-owner of two restaurants with his brother Glenn, a Pasta E Pesce here and in Plainview. "They come for dinner at 8, they see the big show, they see Glenn working the front, real smooth, they hear soft music, they say, 'We got to do this. We got to get a restaurant in Great Neck, make a million.' "

nytimes_articles.headline: Hero and Leander in Yugosalvia
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE INNER SIDE OF THE WIND
Or, the Novel of Hero and Leander.
By Milorad Pavic.
Translated by Christina Pribicevic-Zoric.
174 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

nytimes_articles.headline: G.O.P. Opposition Endangers Campaign Finance Bill
nytimes_articles.abstract: Campaign finance legislation may die in the Senate next week if Democrats cannot find a way to win a few Republican votes by modifying the bill's provisions for public financing of elections.   The issue that seemed the rage last fall when Ross Perot denounced the money in the political system has been stalled in the Senate. And even if legislation to limit spending and curb political action committees survives the Senate, it faces a difficult future in the rest of the legislative process.

nytimes_articles.headline: NIGERIANS IN VOTE FOR CIVILIAN RULE
nytimes_articles.abstract: After nearly a decade of military rule, Nigeria held its first free presidential election today against a backdrop of social unrest and disillusionment.   The exhilaration many Nigerians felt in 1986, when Gen. Ibrahim Babangida promised a swift return to elective civilian rule, has been supplanted by rising anger and anxiety over the sluggish pace of change.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 12-Year-Old With a Taste for Opera
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WITH more than 100 performances under his belt, including one on a forthcoming Kathleen Battle album, Eric Sadkin has a brilliant operatic career ahead of him.  Until his voice changes, that is.

As a member of the Metropolitan Opera's Children's Chorus, Eric, who turned 12 on June 5, has a decidedly different extracurricular activity. While most kids his age were memorizing rap numbers, Eric spent hundreds of hours in a windowless Met subbasement, practicing librettos in a half-dozen foreign languages.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Jersey Q & A: John A. Williams; A Novelist's Journey in Race Relations
nytimes_articles.abstract: THERE came a time, John A. Williams says, when he had to choose between taking an active role fighting racism or take up his pen and demand to be heard. In the end, he decided to be "totally a writer," he says, and his 20 books bear witness to his determination. And come this January, he will be able to devote even more time to his writing when he retires from Rutgers University in Newark, where for the last 14 years he has been a professor of English and journalism.   In an interview at his home in Teaneck, Professor Williams, 67, further talked about the relationship between blacks and whites in general, and blacks and Jews in particular; his his interracial marriage and the experience of teaching at Rutgers.   "No complaints," he insisted. "I'm talking about the facts of racism that have figured prominently in my life." They have also figured in the lives of the heroes of his novels.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alina de la Sierra, Serre L. Murphy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alina Margarita de la Sierra, a daughter of Mrs. George Arellano of New York and Rafael de la Sierra of Coral Gables, Fla., was married yesterday to Serre Livingston Murphy, a son of Ruth Murphy of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and the late J. C. Murphy. The Rev. John Davis performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.   Mrs. Murphy, 27, is an assistant vice president at the Commercial Bank of New York. She graduated from Boston College. Her father is an architectural consultant in Miami. Her mother is a vice president at Brown, Harris, Stevens Inc., a real-estate brokerage in New York. The bride is a stepdaughter of Maita Sanchez and of George Arellano, who is the senior vice president and general manager, in New York, for the paper manufacturer Abitibi-Price Inc.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Global Risk Seen in Nuclear Waste in Oceans
nytimes_articles.abstract: An international group of 116 scientists and radiation experts has reported that nuclear wastes dumped into the world's oceans over the decades apparently pose no global danger.   "Any potential problem would be a local one and would pose no threat on a global scale," the scientists said in a written statement issued on Thursday at a conference in Woods Hole, Mass.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mirrored Images
nytimes_articles.abstract: Body-obsessed Los Angeles seems to be just as enthralled with models as New York. The oh-so-glamorous world of modeling will be the subject of two films in development and a recently signed novel. And who, by the way, were those blond twins everyone spotted on the runway at the Calvin Klein benefit for AIDS Project Los Angeles?    MODEL MOVIE I: Columbia Pictures is developing a film that will take an arch look at the modeling business. The team that put together "Heathers" is behind this one: Daniel Waters as screenwriter and Michael Lehmann as director.

nytimes_articles.headline: Greta Gustavsson, Edward Shugrue 3d
nytimes_articles.abstract: Greta Marie-Sievert Gustavsson, a daughter of Melba Winer of Del Ray Beach, Fla., and the late Erik Gustavsson, was married yesterday to Edward Lincoln Shugrue 3d, the son of Sarah E. Corbin and Mr. Shugrue Jr., both of Boston. The Rev. Robert D. Williams, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.    Mrs. Shugrue is a senior marketing manager in New York for L'Oreal, the cosmetics company based in Paris. She graduated from Trinity College in Hartford. The bride is a stepdaughter of Solomon Winer of Del Ray Beach.

nytimes_articles.headline: True Role Model Is Patrick Ewing
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   With Michael Jordan's alleged gambling legacy, coupled with Charles Barkley's Nike-sponsored message to parents, the inevitable question of "Where are the role models in professional athletics?" has once again been raised.

nytimes_articles.headline: Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption on May 16 with an article about changes in zoning for parking facilities in Philadelphia misidentified the garage at Seventh and Market Streets. It is the Square Industries Garage.

nytimes_articles.headline: Vaughn's Story Is a Tale Times Two
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tell Mo Vaughn that you want to talk to him about his successes this season and he's liable to smile and shake his head.   It does not matter that he is one of the league's most torrid batters, and that in the last 24 games he has hit a sizzling .361, with four home runs and 15 runs batted in.

nytimes_articles.headline: Balanchine: Visions Without The Frills
nytimes_articles.abstract: Although George Balanchine was often choreographically unorthodox, few balletgoers would compare his art with modern dance. Yet it's possible to do so, and not just because he and Martha Graham created "Episodes" in 1959. That project was a pairing, rather than a collaboration: two independently choreographed works to music by Webern that were performed on the same program.    Balanchine, the familiar argument runs, was a product of ballet's most classical traditions.
